topic:
curbing population growth

What measures have been taken worldwide and what countries have been effective in curbing population growth?  

A relevant document must describe an actual case in which population measures have been taken and their results are known. The reduction measures must have been actively pursued; that is, passive events such as disease or famine involuntarily reducing the population are not relevant.


You are a strict classifier for "curbing population growth".

RELEVANT if all of these hold:

- The document's main focus is a national-level policy or program (family-planning laws, contraception access, incentives, legal limits, etc.) that is already implemented or under way.
- It gives evidence of action or impact: quantitative results (birth-rate change, births averted, goals met) or official targets compared with a baseline.

NON-RELEVANT if any of these hold:

- Only proposals or intentions, not yet enacted.
- Sub-national or local schemes without national significance.
- Population control mentioned in passing while discussing another topic (e.g., child labour, environment).
- Passive declines (disease, famine) or purely demographic commentary with no active measures.

NEGATIVE Example:
Title: "Philippines Plans Executive Order on Family Planning"
relevant: false
justification: "Policy only proposed; not yet implemented or evaluated."

POSITIVE Example:
Title: "38 % of Pakistanis Lack Contraceptive Access"
relevant: true
justification: "National programme under way; targets 2.1 % growth by 2003; compares current vs. goal."

1997-01-01 
 India to Introduce New Population Policy 


NEW DELHI, January 1 (Xinhua) -- India is expected to introduce
a new national population policy soon in a bid to curb population
explosion in the country, a government official said here today.


According to the draft of the new national population policy,
which is on the anvil, all new entrants to the government who are
married before the legal age will be debarred from recruitment.


Steps will also be taken to see that the two-child norm is
adopted by government employees both at the national and state
levels. Promotion policies will also be formulated to encourage
the two-child norm in an effort to control growth in the country's
population, which is expected to exceed 1 billion by the turn of
the century.


The new policy will make it mandatory for employers of the
organized sector to provide for group health insurance as
incentive. Besides, legislation will be enacted to debar from
elective offices those people who do not adopt the small family
norm.


The draft population policy also stresses the need for men to
be equal partners in family planning.


It warns that if the population policy goes wrong, "nothing
else will have a chance to go right."

results.content:
2000-04-18 
 Nepali Experts Urges Revision of Population  Policy 


KATHMANDU, April 18 (Xinhua) -- Nepal's national population
policy needs to be revised to curb the rapid growth of population
in the country, experts said here Tuesday.


"There is a need for the Nepali government to revise the
national population policy," said Stephen Chee, representative of
the United Nations Funds for Population Activities, at a 5-day
national population meeting that kicked off Monday.


Although the national population policy formulated in 1983
called for family planning, population growth has been so rapid
that it hindered economic development in the country, said Chee.


Other experts attending the meeting called for the government
to step up population control programs and effective census.


Findings on population development needs to be analyzed and
cross-checked in order to provide information for a better
population policy, they proposed.


According to a paper presented at the meeting, the 1991 census
of Nepal prepared by the central Bureau of Statistics is
unreliable.


"The data on ethnic/caste groups contain a lot of loopholes and
is often unreliable in divergent socio-economic contexts of Nepal,
" the paper said.


Although Nepal started family planning activities in 1959, its
population has seen rapid growth due to slackness in implementing
the national population policy.


At the current annual growth rate of 2.1 percent, the present
22 million population is expected to be doubled in the year 2028,
which will be a heavy burden on the country's poor economy and
scarce resources.


The meeting are co-organized by UN Family Planning Organization
and Tribhuvan University Population Study Faculty. Attending the
meeting are about 30 population experts from Nepal and
international agencies.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-07-22 14:53 
 India To Set Up Population Fund  
By KRISHNAN GURUSWAMY


   NEW DELHI, India (AP) -- Seeking to curb India's high birth rate,
Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee pledged Saturday to set up a
special fund to promote family planning programs across the world's
second most populous nation.


   The government also will set up a group to prepare programs for
specific areas, particularly the northern states, which account for
half of India's population, Vajpayee told the National Commission
on Population in New Delhi.


   India's 1 billion population is larger than any nation except
China. Experts fear that if India's rate of population growth does
not slow, it will become the world's most populated country in 45
years.


   Vajpayee urged companies, voluntary agencies and individuals to
contribute to the National Population Stabilization Fund, which
would direct the money to family planning programs. He gave very
few details of the programs, but said he hoped the population would
stabilize within two decades.


   ''Achieving this is a challenge. But once we overcome the
challenge, we can truly develop our national human resource into a
formidable force ... for all-around prosperity,'' he said.


   The state-run Planning Commission will provide $22.5 million for
the fund, officials said.


   He urged states to make good use of health, education and
related development programs and provide better access to
information on contraception and child care.


   In 1952, India adopted a national family planning program, the
first country in the world to do so. The aim was to ''reduce the
birth rate to the extent necessary to stabilize the population at a
level consistent with the requirement of the national economy.''


   But many Indians, especially women, were without basic health
care, or the literacy skills to understand family planning.


   ''A reality check ... reveals rather disturbing facts,''
Vajpayee said. Nearly one in 10 children dies before the age of
five, he said. Half of the children under the age of four are
undernourished; 30 percent of the newborns are underweight and 60
percent of women are anemic.


   Vajpayee said India must reduce infant and maternal mortality
and meet the demand for contraception. Condoms are available, but
the condom campaign is aimed mostly at preventing sexually
transmitted diseases. In a country where millions are at or below
the poverty level and live in rural areas, spending money on
condoms is not a consideration.


   The National Commission on Population includes federal and state
governments, voluntary agencies and individuals and aims at
promoting better coordination among various agencies to curb
population growth.

results.content:
POPULATION CONTROL MEASURES TO AID WOMEN ARE STUMBLING  
(DW)



   UNITED NATIONS _ A consensus reached at a 180-nation conference
in Cairo, Egypt, five years ago on a new strategy for limiting
world population growth by improving the status of women is now
facing serious religious, ideological and financial difficulties.


   The new strategy would allow the world's population to rise from
its present level of about 5.9 billion people to close to 9.8
billion by the year 2050, and then hold it at around that level.


   But a review conference convened here at the end of last month
to see what progress countries were making toward the Cairo goals
broke up with barely half its work completed.


   Instead of comparing experiences with the Cairo program, the 180
governments represented spent days wrangling over such sensitive
issues as abortion, contraception, sex education for teen-agers and
women's rights to the frustration of the more than 700 private
organizations interested in population and women's issues attending
the session.


   The meeting did not even discuss money for the Cairo program. It
is increasingly unclear whether the world will be able to raise
spending on population policies from $10 billion a year at present
to the $17 billion required under the new strategy in the year
2000, or the nearly $22 billion needed by 2015 at a time when
Western aid to developing nations is falling.


   ``We are having a replay of the differences which surfaced at
Cairo by some of the countries who feel they lost out then,''
acknowledged Bangladesh's representative, Anwarul Karim Chowdhury,
chairman of the review conference, which will reconvene next month
to complete its work.


   ``We are sorry to see a meeting that was supposed to take stock
of how countries are implementing the Cairo program turn into an
attempt to renegotiate that program,'' said Anika Rahman, of the
Center for Reproductive Law and Policy, one of the private lobbying
groups attending the talks.


   Citing a ``huge gap between promises and performance,'' June
Persaud, the Guyanese delegate who spoke for the Group of 77, as
the 130 developing member countries of the United Nations call
themselves, predicted the industrialized world will provide only 33
percent of the $5.7 billion it is supposed to contribute to the
program by 2000.


   Unlike earlier U.N. efforts to curb population growth, which
emphasized numerical targets, the Cairo strategy assumes women will
automatically limit the size of their families as they become
healthier, richer and more educated and enjoy a higher social
status.


   It calls for universal access to reproductive and sexual health
care by 2015 as well as universal access to primary education,
gender equality and sharp reductions in infant, child and maternal
mortality.


   ``Cairo marks a shift in emphasis in population policy from
targets and numbers to improving women's lives,'' said Rosalind P.
Petchesky, of the International Reproductive Rights Research Action
Group. ``You won't stem population growth without bettering the lot
of women.''


   But instead of using last month's review conference to compare
national experiences in carrying out the Cairo program, delegates
found themselves locked in a linguistic struggle over what they
should say about a number of sensitive subjects in the report they
will present to a special session of the U.N. General Assembly in
July.


   A loose coalition of conservative Roman Catholic and Muslim
countries, led by the Vatican and including Argentina, Nicaragua,
Guatemala, Chile, Libya, Sudan, Algeria and Malta, sought
continually to water down commitments made at Cairo.


   They balked, for instance, at a pledge to ensure abortions are
safe for women legally entitled to them.


   They sought to bolster parental authority at the expense of
educating young people about sex and providing them with
independent health care. They opposed any endorsement of so-called
``emergency contraception,'' which destroys a fertilized egg before
it becomes implanted in the uterine wall, making

1999-02-09 
 Tanzanians Urged to Practise Family Planning for 


DAR ES SALAAM, February 9 (Xinhua) -- A Tanzanian government
minister has called on the Tanzanians to practise family planning
so as to curb the heavy deaths of children.


Some 150,000 children die of malnutrition, diarrhoea and
cholera in the east African country per annum while more than one
million others are suffering from malnutrition, Minister of
Community Development, Women Affairs and Children, Mary Nagu, told
the National Assembly in the central city of Dodoma Monday.


The Guardian newspaper Tuesday quoted Nagu as saying that the
government put in place a national policy on security and life as
well as child development in 1993, and another policy in 1996 for
child development, both of which stressed that parents should be
responsible for their children's rights at household level.


She said that her ministry is preparing a program on the
implementation of the two policies, and a program to boost
community development.


The minister appealed to people not to give births to so many
children otherwise they will be unable to meet children's basic
needs of schooling and medical care.


Tanzania's population growth rate stands at 2.8 percent
annually, compared with 3.5 percent of gross domestic product
(GDP).


At a national population and development forum last month,
Tanzanian Prime Minister Frederick Sumaye said that Tanzania, with
a population of 30 million, faces demographic challenges in the
next century.


Sally Fegan-Wyles, resident coordinator of U.N. System in
Tanzania, said that the population growth must decline to give the
country a chance to improve the quality of services for people.


A Planning Commission official stressed that women should be
given more education so that they grow aware of the importance of
family planning.

1996-01-22 12:19 
 Manila to Conduct Family Planning Program 


MANILA, January 22 (Xinhua) -- The Philippine health
authorities today expressed its determination to curb the growth
of the country's population and to attain the ideal growth rate of
two percent before the year 2000.


The Philippines' population has been projected to reach the 70
million mark this year.


According to Health Undersecretary Carmencita Reodica,
Philippine President Fidel Ramos is expected to issue an executive
order for implementing the family planning program at the
country's local government level.


At present, the Philippines has 2.4 percent growth rate, with
about two million births occurring annually.


The country has about 100,000 infants and 4,200 maternal deaths
yearly.

results.content:
2000-06-20 
 "Two Child" Law Does Not Mean Change of Birth Control Policy in China: Officials 


HARBIN, June 20 (Xinhua) -- Officials and experts say the
promulgation of new laws by 27 local governments to allow some
people to have a second child does not mean any big changes have
been made to the country's birth control policy.


"It is just a micro adjustment to meet local specific
conditions," says Song Jie, with the Population Expert Committee
of the State Family Planning Commission.


According to the new laws approved by provinces and autonomous
regions, the right for parents who are both single children to
have a second baby is protected.


Since the late 1970s, China has adopted the one-child policy to
curb its population explosion. The policy has turned China into a
low birth rate country and churned out many young single children.


The policy does not prohibit a husband and wife who are both
single children from bearing a second baby. However, this is the
first time governments have turned to the law to protect the right.


Song says that local governments approved the laws because they
want to tackle the aging population problem and maintain a
population balance.


The proportion of people aged over 70 in the total population
has increased rapidly to 10 percent in the 20-year course of the
one-child policy, which has put pressure on society.


Song says the promulgation of the local laws goes in line with
the normal population growth, and noted that there will not be an
abrupt increase in the Chinese population in the coming years.


A survey in Heilongjiang province shows that 69.9 percent of 1,
0200 respondents aged between 20 and 30 are reluctant to have a
second child.


Li Ling, a company clerk in Harbin, noted that having another
baby "will cost a lot of money and make me and my husband tired."


Xie Zhenming, deputy director of the China Population
Information Research Institute, says that by 2005 some 20 million
marriages will take place in China annually, and only 10 percent
of the couples will be single children.


He said that if each couple has two children, the added
population will be no more than two million every year, which
would have little affect on the nation's population control target.


The Chinese government published a report last month saying
that it will bring the population to under 1.4 billion by 2010 and
the current birth control policy should be stabilized.


Many provinces have increased subsidies for families with one
child.

1999-10-13 
 Population Growth to End in 20 Years in Zhejiang 


HANGZHOU, October 13 (Xinhua) -- The current population growth
in east China's Zhejiang Province will come to an end in about 20
years, according to one senior official.


Zhejiang Governor Chai Songyue said that the population of his
province will be within 45.5 million next year, and climb to 48
million by 2010.


Zhejiang is an economically advanced province, and curbing
population growth will contribute to continued economic growth and
social progress there, he noted.


Since the family planning policy was implemented in China 20
years ago, Zhejiang Province has reported the birth of 20 million
fewer people than would have been the case without this policy.

results.content:
2000-07-19 
 38 Pct of Pakistanis Have No Access to Contraception Facilities 


ISLAMABAD, July 19 (Xinhua) -- Some 38 percent of Pakistanis
have no access to contraception facilities despite the government'
s efforts to curb the alarming growth of population, said the
Associated Press of Pakistan (APP) quoting officials of the
Population Welfare Department.


The lack of facilities will probably hinder the steps of the
current government which is hoping to pull down the annual
population growth rate to 2.1 percent by 2003 from the current 2.3
percent.


Though with one of the oldest population program of Asia,
Pakistan still lags behind in controlling the growth rate as
compared to Iran's 1.6 percent, Bangladesh's 1.5 percent and India
's 1.4 percent, according to APP.


The latest census shows Pakistan now ranks the seventh in the
world with a population of 137.5 million.


One major problem in the population program is the
superstitions of the illiterate women who are a majority in
Pakistan, the officials said.


The officials hoped that by 2003 facilities will be available
for all the people and the contraceptive prevalence rate, which is
mere 30 percent currently, will substantially be enhanced.

results.content:
1997-06-25 
 China Able to Realize Sustainable Development 


UNITED NATIONS, June 24 (Xinhua) -- Chinese State Councillor
Song Jian said here today that China has the ability to realize
sustainable development, though problems remain.


Speaking at a meeting organized by the United Nations
Development Program, Song, the head of the Chinese delegation to
the 19th special session of the U.N. General Assembly, said that
China, as a big country with a population of 1.2 billion, faces
a lot of problems in development.


He mentioned the control of population growth, ecological
farming and clean production as the three of vital importance.


At present, China's farmland averages 10 persons per
hectare. If the population doubles, Song said, there will be an
unbearable pressure on the agricultural resources.


To curb population growth, the family planning policy was
introduced in China in the 1970s and it has been proved to be a
very effective way, he said.


As for ecological farming, Song said it is necessary to protect
farmland and other agricultural resources, adopt eco-friendly
farming mode, expand animal husbandry and fish farming.


It is also necessary to reduce pollution, protect forest,
freshwater resources and biodiversity, the councillor said.


The Chinese government has attached great importance to the
three aspects and is confident to realize sustainable development
despite difficulties, Song said.


Meanwhile, he noted that China remains a developing country
with 58 million people still living in poverty.


China needs international assistance and cooperation and China
hopes to strengthen its cooperation with the United Nations
Development Program, the United Nations Children's Fund and other
U.N. agencies, Song added.

results.content:
With contraceptive costs rising, Indonesia fears baby boom 


	   JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Factories are shut, layoffs are rife,
investors are aloof. Now Indonesia's economic crisis has turned on
a new target: population control.
	   With the price of contraceptives soaring, people are dropping
out of government-backed family planning programs in the nation of
202 million people, the world's fourth most populous.
	   In March, about 443,500 people registered with national
population control programs, down 5,000 from the previous month,
according to government figures.
	   ``People now have to use their money to buy daily essentials
rather than contraceptives,'' The Jakarta Post on Tuesday quoted
Ida Bagus Oka, the state minister of population, as saying.
	   ``This observation has invoked worries of another baby boom era.
It's sure to come if the problem is not immediately addressed,''
Oka said.
	   Indonesia has won international praise for its efforts to curb
population growth by distributing free and subsidized
contraceptives. The annual growth rate has declined from 2.32
percent in the 1980s to 1.6 percent.
	   But people are reluctant to buy contraceptives which are up to
five times more expensive than before the economic crisis hit last
year, Oka said. Most contraceptive materials are imported, making
them more costly because the rupiah is weak against the dollar.
	   The cost of a government-issued package of three condoms has
doubled to 1,000 rupiah (10 U.S. cents).

results.content:
1996-06-21 
 Ten-Year Program Tackles Mental Problems in China 


BEIJING, June 21 (Xinhua) -- The Ministry of Public Health and
the World Health Organization (WHO) have jointly launched a
10-year program to combat mental health problems in China,
reported today's "China Daily".


The so-called "decade of the brain" strategy is designed to
curb increase in mental disorders and promote mental health,
Costae Silva, division chief in charge of mental health for WHO,
said yesterday in Beijing.


The drive will upgrade the country's diagnosis and treatment of
mental illness, to reduce mortality and disability rates resulting
from mental problems and spare medical resources.


China, like the rest of the world, has experienced an increase
in mental health patients in the past decade as a result of rapid
industrialization, growth in social tension and the aging of the
population.


The latest survey of 23,000 people in seven cities showed more
than 11 people in 1,000 suffer from mental disorders. Five in
1,000 people aged 15 and up are mentally disabled.


Another 3.53 per thousand are mentally handicapped, of which
most are children or elderly people.


Since the "decade of the brain" program was initiated in the
United States in 1990, similar activities have been carried out in
six countries.


Mental health will be of vital concern to medical workers in
the next century, and especially important to China which has a
big population and is modernizing very rapidly, said Silva.


He said WHO will continue to train Chinese professionals and
provide technical guidance for the country.

1998-12-01 
 Africa Urged to Press Ahead with Population 


ADDIS ABABA, November 30 (Xinhua) -- African countries were
urged to curb their population growth by further implementation
of their population programs with a view to improving the quality
of life of the people.


Mirian K. Were, Director of the U.N. Fund for Population
Activities (UNFPA) country support team based in Addis Ababa made
the call Monday while Opening the 1998 consultation of UNFPA
representatives and UNFPA country support teams.


Mirian K. Were said, "If we are successful in our work in
supporting country program implementation, the country support
teams can contribute in a very substantial way to the improvement
of the quality of life of people of Africa."


UNFPA country support team based in Addis Ababa provides
technical services in population issues to 13 countries in East,
Central and Anglophone West Africa.


The director said participants of the on-going consultation
have the responsibility of rising to the challenge of
contributing effectively to the improvement of the quality of
life in the continent.


"Working together, we can help countries that are our
responsibility to live up to th potential of UNFPA," she added.


African population growth rate is the highest in the world.
Sub-Saharan Africa is projected to almost double itself from 778
million in 1998 to 1,317 million in 2020.

results.content:
1998-08-23 08:55 
 Jordan Seeking Extension of IMF-WB Economic Reform 


AMMAN, August 23 (Xinhua) -- Jordan is seeking to extend the
economic reform program co-sponsored by the International Monetary
Fund (IMF) and World Bank (WB) in a bid to spur the economic
development, the semi-official Jordan Times reported Sunday.


The newly-appointed Jordanian cabinet has applied for the
extension for at least one year, citing Jordan's economy will fall
short of the expectations of the 1988-1999 IMF-WB program when it
expires in February 1999.


The program has succeeded on the macro-economic level,
including stabilizing the exchange rate between the U.S. dollar
and Jordan's currency dinar and increasing Jordan's foreign
exchange reserves.


But it has failed to help the kingdom achieve sustainable
economic growth, the paper quoted economists and bankers as
saying.


The economic growth was healthy and sustainable only in the
first three years of the IMF-WB reform, but after that it became
volatile and even decreased to 0.8 percent in 1996, much lower
than the 5.2 percent target set by the previous government, said
Fahed Fanek, a leading economist at the Privatization Unite of the
Prime Minister's Office.


Jordan's economic growth rate in 1997 was estimated at 2.5 to 3
percent, and the government has revised its forecast of the 1998
growth rate from 6 percent to 3.2 percent and even set a 2.2
percent target for 1999.


Lower growth rates have led to declining living standards,
higher unemployment and increased poverty, in view of a higher
annual population growth rate of 3.5 percent, said the paper.


The unemployment rate in the kingdom was estimated at 27
percent in March this year. About 45 percent of the families are
living under the poverty line, earning less than 210 U.S. dollars
a month.


With the one-year extension of the IMF-WB reform, Jordanian new
government hopes to realize a 6 percent economic growth rate in
2000 so to curb unemployment, combat poverty and improve
people's living standard.


Prime Ministers Fayez Tarawneh, who formed the government last
Thursday, has placed economic development as the priority of his
government. He has began preparations for the extension of the
IMF-WB reform program and seeking other international help to help
reinvigorate Jordan's economy.

results.content:
1996-09-25 
 Central Conference on Poverty-Relief Ends (2) 


Vice-Premier Jiang Chunyun delivered the closing speech at
today's meeting. Jiang said the main goal of the poverty-relief
effort and development work is to solve the problems of food and
clothing for the poor, so that by the end of the century, all
Chinese will have enough food and clothing, except those who rely
on government subsidiaries, such as the handicapped, widowers,
and widows.


He urged all provinces, ethnic minority autonomous regions and
municipalities to formulate and perfect their poverty-alleviation
programs.


The meeting has selected nine economically-powerful provinces
and municipalities and four cities in the east to help 10 poor
provinces and autonomous regions. Jiang called this a strategic
measure for accelerating the poverty-relief campaign and gradually
shrinking the economic gap between the east and west.


He urged the poor areas which are slow in developing the
socialist market economy, to further free themselves from old
ideas and update their viewpoints.


The poverty-stricken areas should improve their ecological and
agricultural conditions, develop farm technology and curb
population growth, Jiang said.


The vice-premier called on all related departments and
localities to attach great importance to the implementation of
poverty-alleviation policies and timely allocation of the funds.


To realize the national poverty-alleviation program is the
urgent demand of the country's 65 million poor farmers, Jiang
noted.


"It is the country's top priority and, however difficult the
task, we must reach the established goal without hesitation," he
said.

1996-02-15 19:32 
 Egyptian Population Reaches 60 Million 


CAIRO, February 15 (Xinhua) -- The Egyptian population has
reached over 60 million, according to a report released today by
the Central Agency for Public Mobilization and Statistics (CAPMAS).


The population numbered 60.236 million on January 1, 1996,
increasing by 1.358 million from January 1, 1995, Egypt's Middle
East News Agency quoted the report as saying.


During the year, the report added, the population increased by
104,000 on the average every month, or 3,447 a day, or one person
every 25.7 seconds.


The Egyptian government has vowed to tackle the problem of
overpopulation, which is a headache to a country with almost 96
percent of its territories covered by desert.


Egypt has sought to curb population growth through an
aggressive family-planning program.

results.content:
1996-02-26 20:35 
 China Promotes Reproductive Rights and Health 


UNITED NATIONS, February 26 (Xinhua) -- China has made great
efforts to enable its people to better exercise their reproductive
rights and improve reproductive health, a Chinese representative
said here today.


Speaking at the U.N. Commission on Population and Development
opened here this morning, Chinese representative and Vice-Minister
of the State Family Planning Commission Peng Yu said that the
promotion of family planning is the major pillar of the nation's
population program, including the reproductive health program.


Following the principles of the International Conference on
Population and Development, the Chinese government has formulated
the Program for Promotion of Family Planning, which calls for the
integration of the family planning with the development of rural
economy, eradication of peasants' poverty and realization of their
family happiness through the provision of better services, she
said.


China has strengthened training of family planning workers at
different levels since 1994. The UNFPA-funded project has been
carried out in 19 provinces and autonomous regions where 60,000
rural family planning workers have improved their capabilities in
recent years, she noted.


The State Family Planning Commission, State Education
Commission, Ministry of Health and five other departments have
also promoted sex education, including sexual and reproductive
health counseling services for newly-weds in 60 percent of
localities.


In the field of maternal and child health care, China
promulgated the Mother and Infant Health Law in late 1994, which
stipulates that the medical and health departments should provide
the citizens with pre-marital health services, mother and infant
health services, including sexual and reproductive health care.


Chinese media has also disseminated knowledge on prevention of
sexually transmitted diseases, HIV and AIDS in addition to
providing treatment of those diseases.


On achievements of the family planning program, she said that
China has curbed the trends of excessive population growth: the
total fertility rate went down from 5.81 births per woman to the
replacement level from 1970 to 1995.


However, China is still confronted with a quite grave
population situation in a considerable long period. The total
population on the Chinese mainland exceeded 1.2 billion last year;
there will be 1.3 billion in 2000 and 1.4 billion in 2010, she
noted.


The second session of the Commission on Population and
Development will be ended on Friday. The central theme at the
session is reproductive rights and health, including such issues
as family planning, maternal and child health, abortion and
information on securityy.

results.content:
1998-07-12 
 Bangladesh to Initiate Time-Befitting Population 


DHAKA, July 12 (Xinhua) -- The Bangladeshi government is
politically determined and committed to initiating a
time-befitting population policy, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina
said here Sunday.


Her government would implement the policy in letter and spirit
to stop a population boom in the country, Hasina told the
inaugural session of the World Population Day function, jointly
organized by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare and the
United Nations Population Fund.


She underscored the need to create mass awareness among the
people so that the movement for curbing population explosion in
the country could be a total success.


The poor parents of the country wished to produce many children
so that they could be helped by their offspring when getting old,
she said, which had caused the rapid population growth.


"If we could develop a kind of social security for them ... the
poor people would not go for many children," the prime minister
noted.


Population was a kind of asset for some countries, but it was a
matter of deep concern for developing countries like Bangladesh,
she pointed out.


Her government would spend 28.59 billion taka (about 608
million U.S. dollars) in the population sector by the year 2002
under the country's Fifth Five-Year Plan, she added.


Hasina called on political parties, social and voluntary
organizations to make an united effort to make the huge population
of the country into potential human resources.


Bangladesh, with an area of about 144,000 square kilometers and
a population of about 127 million at present, has one of the
world's highest population density of about 880 people per square
kilometer.

results.content:
1999-01-16 
 Population Growth Rate in Tanzania Too High: PM 


DAR ES SALAAM, January 15 (Xinhua) -- Tanzanian Prime Minister
Frederick Sumaye said Friday that Tanzania's population growth
rate is too high to guarantee sustainable development.


Opening a national population and development forum, Sumaye
said the country's population growth rate stands at 2.8 percent,
compared with gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate at
approximately three to four percent per annum.


"In order to be able to cater for such a population growth rate
we need an economic growth rate of between 8 and 10 percent," he
said.


"Dealing with the demographic challenges and achieving a
balance between economic growth and population size is the main
issue for us as a nation as we approach the next millenium," he
said.


Sumaye did not say what measures will be taken to curb the
population growth. Instead, he called on people to work hard to
promote economic growth.


Sally Fegan-Wyles, resident coordinator of U.N. System in
Tanzania, said the current growth rate of 2.8 percent means that
the country's present population of some 30 million will double in
25 years.


"While we can hope that economic growth will accelerate,
population growth must also decline, to give Tanzania a chance to
improve the quality of services for their people," she told the
meeting.


The major objective of the meeting is to review implementation
of the Program of Action adopted by the International Conference
on Population and Development (ICPD) held in Cairo in 1994. The
meeting is also a preparatory forum for the Hague Forum planned to
convene next month.


Sumaye said Tanzania has done a lot toward implementing ICPD
resolutions. For example, on gender equality and empowerment of
women, the government has taken measures to improve girls'
universal access to education. Meanwhile, women are guaranteed 15
percent representation for parliamentary seats and 25 percent for
the local government council's seats.


He added that the government in collaboration with
non-government organizations (NGOs), has increased the number of
service delivery points in the rural areas where the majority of
the people are living.


Despite the achievements, the prime minister acknowledged that
there still exist customary laws and practices which discriminate
women on issues of property rights and inheritance. At the same
time, he said funds allocated to reproductive health programs have
been insufficient.


Charles Mutalemwa, acting permanent secretary in the Planning
Commission, told a press conference at the end of the meeting that
the Tanzanian government will further carry out family planning
education among people, especially women.

results.content:
WORLD CONFERENCE SPLITS ON CURBING POPULATION GROWTH 



   UNITED NATIONS _ With time running out, a 180-nation conference
struggling to repair a shattered consensus on limiting world
population growth was still divided Tuesday over issues ranging
from abortion and family planning to sex education in schools.


   On Wednesday, the conference is supposed to present an updated
action plan to a special session of the U.N. General Assembly. But
if the conference is still not ready, it may continue its
discussions in parallel with the General Assembly debate.


   But Tuesday night a comparatively small group of conservative
Roman Catholic and Muslim developing countries, with strong support
from the Vatican, was blocking final agreement on several key
aspects of the plan.


   Five years ago in Cairo, the countries meeting this week agreed
that the best way to curb population growth is not by setting
numerical targets and mounting birth-control campaigns. Instead,
they decided to try to improve the social status, education and
health of young women and men in the belief they will then limit
the size of their families.


   This so-called Cairo strategy is designed to let the world's
population rise from some 6 billion at present to 9.8 billion by
2050 and thereafter hold it at around that level.


   But difficulties arose last March when the nations who had first
agreed upon the Cairo strategy met at the United Nations in New
York to draw up an action plan for completing it.


   Conservatives used this meeting to reopen key portions by
inserting language playing down family planning, restricting
abortion and asserting parental control over children's health and
sex education.


   While the composition of this group varies from issue to issue,
prominent members include Libya, Sudan, Morocco, Guatemala,
Nicaragua and Argentina as well as the Vatican.


   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)


   Paying for the Cairo program is also problematic.


   On Tuesday night the conference agreed to reaffirm earlier
pledges on financing the program, which is expected to cost $17
billion in 2000, rising to $21.7 billion by 2017.


   The pledges commit developing countries to pay two-thirds of the
total and the industrialized world the rest. But both are well
behind on their obligations so far. Industrialized countries, which
promised at Cairo to pay $5.7 billion a year, have contributed only
$1.9 billion a year on average so far. Developing nations, which
were supposed to pay $ 11.3 billion annually, have paid $7.8
billion a year on average, with most of that money being spent by
China, India, Brazil, Mexico and Indonesia.


   Donors have done even worse, however. Their total contributions
are running at $1.9 billion a year, although at Cairo they pledged
to provide $5.7 billion annually.


   After the April meeting failed to reach agreement the conference
was reconvened here last week. But Tuesday night it was still
divided on several important issues.


   For example, conservatives dislike a call for governments to
provide young people with confidential advice on contraceptives and
reproductive health care, demanding greater parental oversight.


   ``If the services are not confidential, young people won't use
them,'' said Ardrienne Germaine, president of the International
Women's Health Coalition, a New York-based women's group.


   Also unpopular with conservative groups is a Mexican proposal to
encourage sex education in school curricula in order to promote
``responsible sexual behavior'' and to protect adolescents from
``pregnancy, unsafe abortion and sexually transmitted diseases.''


   Although most nations in the world support the Cairo program,
the small conservative faction is able to exercise disproportionate
influence over the roughly 130 developing members of the United
Nations, because these countries try to vote as a bloc.


   And all members accept that an agreement that is primarily
intended to help the developing world reduce its growing population
will have little value if these countries

results.content:
1999-01-09 17:50 
 Jordan's Lower Chamber Starts Debating 1999 Budget 


AMMAN, January 9 (Xinhua) -- Jordan's lower house of
parliament, the House of Representatives, on Saturday started its
debate on the 1999 budget.


The budget of 2.16 billion Jordanian dinars (3.24 billion
U.S. dollars), presented to the House by Finance Minister Mishail
Marto last December, put the current expenditure at 1.68 billion
dinars (2.37 billion dollars).


The projected capital expenditure was 477 million dinars (667.8
millions dollars), which many House members and analysts
considered too low for a robust economic recovery.


A 7 percent budget deficit proposed by the government was in
line with the target set by the International Monetary Fund (IMF)
for renewing its financial aid to the reform program of the
kingdom.


Jordan and the IMF are expected to sign an agreement later this
month on a new three-year reform program following the kingdom's
failure to achieve sustainable economic growth in the past three
years.


The government believed the 1999 budget would help spur the
sluggish economy which it blamed for instabilities in Iraq,
Israel, plunging oil prices and a decline in overseas remittances.


On the other hand, the government feared measures to control
deficits would further push the economy into recession.


Critics of the budget also echoed such concerns. They believe
the government was unable to solve its twin dilemma of curbing
unemployment and poverty while putting a lid on public
expenditures, and keeping the deficit below 7 percent.


With the 7 percent deficit ceiling, the government can hardly
achieve a growth rate higher than 3 percent in 1999, economists
said.


They believed Jordan needed at least a 6 percent economic
growth to cope with the population growth rate of the country,
which stood at 3 percent last year.

1996-06-20 
 China's Development: Contributions Not Threats to World Peace (3) 


The real reason for the fact that some Westerners have
characterized China's recent relatively speedy growth as the
"China threat" is nothing more than an attempt to curb the
country's further development.


In the eyes of some anti-China forces in the West, the article
said, development and the power of socialist China pose a serious
threat to them; they are afraid of the successes of socialist
China, which might threaten their dominant position in the new
world order.


"They are not clear that in today's world, it is impossible for
them to curb China's development. Some of the sensible people have
pointed out that curbing China will only produce disastrous
consequences," the article said.


The article also said that such a policy of "curbing" is not
new to the Chinese people. When new China was founded in the late
40's, some countries had already enforced the so-called curbing
and "blockading" policies, but to no avail.


The article reassured readers that no force whatsoever in the
world can impede the progress of 1.2 billion Chinese people.

results.content:
1999-02-28 
 Mexican President Calls for efforts to Curb Forest Fires 


MEXICO CITY, February 27 (Xinhua) -- Mexican President Ernesto
Zedillo Saturday called on his nationals to prevent forest fires
and to recover forested areas lost until now.


He said 14,445 fires broke out last year, affecting more than
582,000 hectares of land. Of the total 405,000 were ecological
forest systems and the rest grassland.


In 1995 there were 78 million hectares of forested land, and
now only 53 million, and in less than 50 years the country has
lost almost one third of its forests and jungles, he said.


"We have to stop the extinction of the forests and jungles,"
Zedillo said. "We cannot permit this wealth to continue being
destroyed, which our children and all the future generations of
Mexico need."


Among the causes of the destruction, he said, are the
population growth and irrational destruction of the forest
resources, as well as the primitive methods for land cultivation,
such as the cutting of trees and burning of grass to prepare the
soil for sowing.


The president warned the impact of the forest destruction has
started to be felt, citing as an example the bad weather that
affected the southern state of Chiapas last September due to the
cutting of trees and the erosion in the higher lands of that
region.


As for the official move in forest protection, the president
said protected natural areas of 955,000 hectares of jungles and
forests have been created, and this year and the next another 660,
000 hectares will be added.


The National Reforestation Program will be promoted more
dynamically, under which 100 million trees were planted in 674,000
hectares, and there are plans to plant 285,000 more trees before
the end of the year.


The National Fire Prevention Program is already in force and a
big budget has been allocated to it, he said.

results.content:
1996-05-08 
 World Bank Lauds Tanzania 


DAR ES SALAAM, May 8 (Xinhua) -- The World Bank has commended
the Tanzanian government for its policies, saying Tanzania was
now doing well economically than many countries in the sub-
Saharan Africa.


The World Bank Resident Representative, Ronald Brigish,
told a press conference here on Tuesday, that while the Gross
Domestic Product (GDP) growth in sub-Saharan Africa was about
3.0 percent, Tanzania registered a GDP growth of 4.0 percent.


Brigish, however, said that Tanzania had bright prospects
and could register economic growth of even 10 percent a year
like Uganda.


He added Tanzanian government should continue with such policies,
striving to attain efficiency in tax collection, liberalisation
of trade and curbing budget deficits should be continued, he
stressed.


"Tanzania is better off economically than many sub-saharan
countries, but it still has budget deficits which in turn lead
to high inflation rates at around 30 percent", Brigish said.


He noted that he was looking forward to increased co-operation
between the Tanzania government and multilateral donor institutions
like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).


Brigish pointed out that the economies of sub-saharan
African were reportedly on the rise, a trend that has been
attributed to higher commodity prices in the world market,
liberal economic plicies and peaceful transition to multi-party
politics.


Giving the highlights of the world bank report entitled
Global Economic Prospects and Developing Countries 1996,
Brigish said the income of individual sub-Sahara Africans
was growing and had registered a highest average growth rate
since 1989.


He said 30 countries out of 48 in the region, recorded GDP
increases of more than 3.0 percent a year, a level that was
slightly above population growth.


Brigish said third world countries like tanzania could
benefit provided they exploit most of the areas in which they
have comparative advantages, citing examples as a lot of potential
in horticulture, farming of flowers and etc. enditem

results.summary: 2000-02-04 Ghana to Kick off Campaign for Curbing AIDS NAIROBI, February 4 (Xinhua) -- A new n ... ol and the time to act is now. The gains and growth made in agriculture could be eroded because
results.content:
2000-02-04 
 Ghana to Kick off Campaign for Curbing AIDS 


NAIROBI, February 4 (Xinhua) -- A new national crusade, to be
implemented in two phases over a period of two years against the
HIV/AIDS scourge, is to be launched next week, Ghana News Agency
reported Friday.


The "Love Life, Stop AIDS" campaign would focus on prevention
of HIV transmission and compassion for those who are HIV positive,
Ghanaian Minister of Communications John Mahama was quoted as
saying at a press briefing here on Thursday night.


The campaign, to be launched by First lady Nana Konadu Agyeman
Rawlings, will synthesize lessons learnt from fighting AIDS in
Africa over the past decade, he said.


Mahama warned that the serious spectre of AIDS poses a real
danger that could spiral out of control and the "time to act is
now".


"The gains and growth made in agriculture could be eroded
because the most productive segment of the population who should
sustain this progress will no more be around if this menace is not
checked," he said.


Meanwhile, Deputy Minister of Employment and Social Welfare Ama
Benyiwa- Doe said the current national prevalence rate of AIDS is
4.6 percent.


She called on all stakeholders to join in the formulation,
implementation, control and monitoring of strategies and programs
aimed at reducing and consequently eradicating AIDS from the
country.

results.content:
2000-02-23 
 Mounting Fiscal Deficit Most Challenging Problem for India: President 


NEW DELHI, February 23 (Xinhua) -- Growing fiscal deficit has
become one of the most challenging macro-economic management
problems faced by India, President K. R. Narayanan said here on
Wednesday in his opening address to the Parliament's budget
session.


Mounting fiscal deficit has led to deteriorating fiscal
position of both the central government and the states, which is a
situation that "needed to be urgently reversed," said the
president.


The deficit also reduces public investment, crowds out private
investment, raises interest rates and generates inflationary
pressure, said Narayanan.


According to the president, gross fiscal deficit of Indian
states has touched a record 750 billion rupees (17.44 billion U.S.
dollars), or 4.3 percent of India's gross domestic product (GDP),
while the burden of interest payments continued to be large at
above 4 percent of the GDP.


If India wants to sustain accelerated growth with high
employment coupled with modest inflation, he said, the growing
fiscal deficit needs to be contained.


"We have to adopt measures to curb the rising trend of non-plan
expenditure," elaborated the president. "These require difficult
decisions on expenditure control, downsizing of government and
austerity in spending," he said.


India can truly hope to achieve growth rates of well over seven
percent in the coming years once it achieves fiscal consolidation,
Narayanan predicted.


"If sacrifices have to be made for achieving this challenging
goal, they are well-worth making because the long-term rewards of
restructuring will benefit all Indians and will far outweigh the
temporary costs," he asserted.


He said that the Indian government would announce its new
agricultural policy and vigorously pursue a coherent plan of
economic reforms.


The program of disinvestment and restructuring of public sector
undertakings also needs to be accelerated, he added.


The government would also make conscious and concerted efforts
to bring the fruits of economic reforms to those regions and
communities that have so far not benefited from them, Narayanan
said.


"We must lose no more time to eradicate mass poverty, remove
illiteracy and assure basic minimum services to all our fellow
citizens," he said, adding "While accomplishing this historic task,
we must simultaneously strengthen social justice, promote gender
justice, remove regional imbalances and bridge the rural-urban
divide."


He pointed out that the country cannot achieve the strength and
prosperity that it desires and is capable of if vast areas and
large sections of the population remain deprived and poor.


"Faster economic growth is a precondition for removing social
and regional imbalances in development," he stressed.

results.content:
1999-12-13 
 China Curbs Growth of New-Poor Population 


YINCHUAN, December 13 (Xinhua) -- China is taking measures to
prevent people who have escaped from poverty from returning to it.


Thanks to three decades of effort, the number of rural people
who living below the poverty line has been reduced from 250
million in 1978 to 42 million last year.


Nevertheless, due to a poor ecological environment, backward
infrastructure, and a high rate of illiteracy, about 10 percent of
the people who become better-off because of government aid return
to poverty again. The figure can rise to 20 percent in years when
severe natural disasters occur.


In Xihaigu in northwest China's Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region,
one of the eight poorest areas in the country, as much as 50
percent of the people who had become better-off became needy again
in recent years.


To curb the reoccurrence of a new-poverty population, the
Agricultural Bank of China has issued more than 8 billion yuan in
the form of small loans to support 1.3 million households in their
fight against poverty.


Meanwhile, over 20 provinces and autonomous regions have also
granted small loans to families with financial needs to develop
farm and sideline production.


The State Office for Poverty Alleviation and Development has
decided to continue to assist those needy counties which had
become relatively better-off by offering them a longer period of
preferential policies.

results.content:
1996-07-26 
 Zimbabwe Government to Press Ahead With Reforms 


HARARE, July 25 (Xinhua) -- The Zimbabwean government today
said it will press ahead with tough economic reforms and solve a
serious unemployment crisis which it admitted threatens social
and political stability.


Presenting the 1996/97 budget speech to parliament, Finance
Minister Herbert Murerwa said the government is already preparing
to launch the second phase of the reforms, and consolidate on
success achieved during the first five year of the program, which
ended last year.


He said growth will support employment creation by the private
sector, the lynch-pin of Zimbabwe's economic success.


Economic growth during the first phase of the reforms was
disappointing, averaging one percent against a target of five
percent, while population growth soared by 3.1 percent, according
to the minister.


The major setback, he said, is the failure by the government
to reduce the budget deficit as a percentage of gross domestic
product, despite pledges to donors to cut it from 10 percent to
five percent of GDP by the end of 1995.


In addition, huge parastatal losses and the resultant
subsidies have forced the government to increase borrowing on the
domestic market, further fueling inflationary pressures.


As the government prepares to launch the second phase of the
reforms, he said, it will redouble efforts to curb spending, and
this will call for further stringent measures to ensure
ministries spend within their means.

results.content:
2000-02-15 
 Gansu Has 230,000 Fewer Babies Born in 1999 


LANZHOU, February 15 (Xinhua) -- There were 230,000 fewer
babies born in Gansu Province in northwest China last year thanks
to a series of measures adopted by local family planning
departments.


Last year, the population growth rate of Gansu, one of the
poorest provinces in China, dropped from 10.4 per thousand in 1998
to 9.17 per thousand in 1999, the first time that the rate has
been below 10 per thousand.


To curb the rapid population growth rate and achieve sustained
social and economic development, the provincial government set
aside 20 million yuan to establish a special dual-functional fund
both for eliminating poverty and for encouraging the
implementation of the country's family planning policy. Now the
fund has had 100 million yuan for the purpose.


As a result, 107,000 of 414,000 poverty-stricken households
have eliminated poverty. The average per capita income of 50,000
households reached or exceeded the level of local farmers. This
has encouraged more people to have fewer babies.


Located in a land-locked arid region of northwest China, Gansu
has historically been one of the poorest provinces in China. The
number of poor farmers with annual per capita income of less than
200 yuan (24 U.S. dollars) was 12.54 million 20 years ago, making
up 74.5 percent of the province's total rural population.

results.content:
1999-03-13 
 Jiang Calls for Strengthened Family Planning Work 


BEIJING, March 13 (Xinhua) -- Chinese President Jiang Zemin
today called for strengthened family planning work to curb China's
population growth.


Speaking at an afternoon work conference on population control
and resource and environmental protection, Jiang said population
control deals with a wide range of difficult issues and must not
be relaxed.


Jiang, who also serves as general secretary of the Communist
Party of China (CPC) Central Committee, pointed out that China
should further improve its population macro-control, family
planning management and social insurance systems in accordance
with the development needs of socialist market economy.


Education, legal, economic and administrative measures should
be adopted to ensure effective population control work. Long-term
efforts should center on controlling the nation's population
growth in line with well established goals, said Jiang.


He pointed to the difficulties involving population control in
rural areas, and noted that experience shows that the key to the
problem lies in the establishment of grass roots organizations in
the countryside. Specialized personnel should be assigned to
direct the work, funds should be allocated and related regulations
should be adopted, according to Jiang.


He added that population control should be directly linked with
economic development and helping farmers gain prosperity. Jiang
said policies should be introduced to help farmers solve problems
related to daily life and production and encourage them to
participate in family planning.

results.content:
1998-01-03 
 Year-ender: France Achieves Initial Economic Success in 1997 


PARIS, January 3 (Xinhua) -- Since the French Socialist Party
won the general elections at the end of May, the new government
led by Prime Minister Lionel Jospin has adopted a series of
economic measures with initial success achieved.


In the general elections, the Socialists, Communists and
Ecologists took power from the rightwing coalition of the Gaullist
Rally for Republic (RPR) headed by President Jacques Chirac and
the Union for French Democracy (UDF).


The resignation of the rightwing government was due to slow
economic recovery, increasing unemployed population, serious
social injustice and the lack of public confidence in the future,
which are also challenging the new leftwing government.


The top problems facing the new government are the launch of
the European single currency in 1999 and greater European
integration.


Under the Maastricht Treaty, only the country with the state
financial deficit less than three percent of its gross national
product (GNP) is qualified for joining the Euro.


As it tried to meet the criteria for joining the Euro by
tightening expenditures to control the budget deficit, the
leftwing government attached importance to social problems.


Pushed by the French initiatives, the Amsterdam Treaty signed
by the European Union in October, the ratification of the
Maastricht Treaty and the convocation of the Job Summit in
Luxembourg in November have promised to maintain public welfare
and protect national interest.


Unemployment and various social crises caused by injustice are
for the moment two major problems for the French government, whose
success mainly depends on its ability to address the woes with
creativity and confidence.


The new government has adopted an employment program for the
youth and the 35-hour work week plan, in addition to reforming the
tax system for social insurance.


It has also taken a series of measures to adjust the allocation
of government financial budget and increase the tax rate of
interest for big enterprises.


The government has laid a foundation for solving the
unemployment problem by increasing state income and cutting
improper expenditures, so as to stimulate economic growth and
create job opportunities.


Some observers said that the economic and social policies
adopted by the leftwing government have kept a balance between the
interests of enterprises and the public by stressing social
justice, while others criticized the government for lacking
creativity in curbing unemployment.


Meanwhile, business representatives said that the increase of
tax revenues of enterprises and reduction of legal work hours of
employees would hurt the competitiveness of enterprises and even
hinder the development of the national economy.


In any case, the leftwing government has made some economic
achievements since it came to power more than half a year ago.


According to the recent statistics released by the French
Finance Ministry, the deficit in 1997 was estimated to have
dropped to 3.1 percent, close to the criteria set for joining the
Euro.


The rise of dollar and increasing demands in other countries
this year have also helped France achieve a favorable balance of
foreign trade and overall industrial development.


In 1997, the government continued to carry out the policy of
low interest rate which stimulated the economic growth; thus, the
industrial investment and domestic consumption in France this year
are predicted to increase.


The economic growth rate in France this year is expected to
increase one percentage point to 2.3 percent and the growth rate
in 1998 is likely to rise to about 3 percent, according to the
estimations of both the government and research institutions.

results.content:
1998-07-10 
 UNEP Puts Out E. African Atlas of Coastal 


NAIROBI, July 9 (Xinhua) -- The United Nations Environment
Program (UNEP) Thursday urged to curb mainkind's land-based
activity from oceans when launching the Kenyan volume of East
African Atlas of Coastal Resources, the first one in the region.


The atlas is part of a common action plan on ocean
conservation reached by governments of Somalia, Kenya, Tanzania,
Mozambique, the Comoros, Madagascar, Mauritius, Seychelles and
Reunion in 1985.


Volumes of Tanzania, Seychelles, Mozambique and the Comoros of
their coastal resources atlas are coming soon, said UNEP
Assistant Executive Director Jorge Illucea.


Meanwhile, he expressed concern about the sagging world's
coastline and the continuous degradation of the marine
environment due to human activities.


"It is estimated that 77 percent of all pollution entering the
world ocean can be traced to land-based activities," he said.


"We have increasingly seen that the activities of billions of
us are affecting not only the land, but also the entire planet,
including the 71 percent of it covered by oceans, coastal waters
and estuaries," he noted.


As a result of the shrinking coastlines, about 6.4 billion
people will reside in coastal areas worldwide in three decades,
compared with currently 3.6 billion people, or nearly two-thirds
of the global population.


Partly due to the rising population pressures, in much of
Asia, Africa and parts of Latin America, coastal fisheries are
chronically over-exploited, the senior UNEP official sighed.


He called for integrated coastal zone management strategies
which would take account of population growth and distribution,
urbanization trends, consumption patterns, generation of wastes
and the use of available resources.


Meanwhile, he spoke highly of the release of the atlas on
coastal resources in east Africa, also on the west Indian Ocean
region, saying that accurate scientific data is key to the
protection of the environment and sustainable development.

results.content:
1997-03-26 
 Sino-US Environment, Development Forum Held in Beijing (1) 


BEIJING, March 25 (Xinhua) -- Chinese Premier Li Peng and US
Vice-President Al Gore presided over a Sino-US Forum on
Environment and Development at the Great Hall of the People here
this morning.


The forum was aimed at exchanging views on the environment and
development between the two countries, and exploring ways of
cooperation in science and technology, environment, energy, and
business.


Since early this century, tremendous changes have occurred on
the earth, which sustains human existence. What is noteworthy is
how science and technology have developed by leaps and bounds, and
productive forces have been greatly raised, Li Peng said at the
forum.


At the same time, soaring population has posed a series of
challenges to economic and social development. Natural resources
are excessively exploited, and large amounts of pollutants are
discharged, the premier said.


"At this historical moment at the turn of the century, what
kind of earth will be left to our coming generations is a major
topic of common concern to the people in all countries around the
world," he said.


Li noted that the Chinese government has been paying great
attention to environmental and development matters. Based on its
own conditions, China has chosen a road of revitalizing the nation
with science and education and sustainable development, a road
which correctly deals with the relations between economic growth
and environment, population, and resources.


China has scored remarkable progress in achieving sustained and
rapid economic expansion, basically curbing the deterioration of
environmental quality with environmental protection as the basic
national policy, preliminarily putting fast growing population
under control, saving existing resources while exploring new
resources, and actively promoting international cooperation in
environmental protection, Li said.


However, China still faces arduous work and severe challenges
in the fields of environment and development, Li noted.

results.content:
1996-06-25 
 Premier Li Peng Calls for Protection of Cultivated Land (1) 


BEIJING, June 25 (Xinhua) -- Premier Li Peng today made a
national televised speech, saying that safeguarding China's
cultivated land is protecting the 'lifeline' of the Chinese people.


Li's speech marked the Sixth National Land Day, and the tenth
anniversary of the implementation of the Land Management Law, both
falling today.


"The bottleneck of land, especially cultivated land, has long
curbed the growth of agriculture and the national economy in
China," Li said.


China has limited land resources in reserve, but its population
is expected to climb from the present 1.2 billion to 1.3 billion
by the end of this century.


With economic growth and the growing population, the conflict
between humans and land will become even more acute in China, the
premier said.


"The protection of cultivated land presents a big issue, which
is of significance to the fundamental and long-term interests of
the whole nation, the survival and development of our generation
and our offsprings, social development and the stability of the
country," Li said, adding that "such an issue can never be
neglected."


The Communist Party and the Chinese government have attached
great importance to land management and the protection of
cultivated land. Since 1986, the country has implemented the Land
Management Law and a series of major principles, policies, laws
and regulations concerning land.


By protecting land, China has managed to feed 22 percent of the
world's population with only seven percent of the world's arable
land, and continued to develop its agriculture, yet the land
situation is still stark, Li warned.

results.content:
1998-12-07 
 Roundup: Zambia Takes Steps to Curb Crimes 


LUSAKA, December 6 (Xinhua) --The Zambian government has waged
a fight against the escalating crimes and called on all Zambians
to fully cooperate with it.


Zambian Information and Broadcasting Minister, Newstead Zimba,
said here Sunday that the government has made the determination to
curb the rampant crimes and steps have been taken for this purpose.


The measures include tight scrutiny of people getting national
registration cards, keeping all refugees coming from neighboring
countries in designated areas, and the identification, arrest and
deportation of illegal immigrants.


Others will be to enhance police training, introduce more
radio and television programs on community-based policing on
crime, promote neighborhood watch schemes and to urge the public
to cooperate with the police in identifying criminals.


And the police have been given the mandate to recruit more
officers in the fight against the sophisticated criminals,
according to the minister.


While briefing the press, Zimba, who is also chief government
spokesman, declared that the government takes full control of the
deteriorated crime situation in the country and that a number of
criminals have been identified and are being brought to book.


Loopholes through which crimes have been perpetrated are being
sealed, Zimba said, adding that high crime areas will be
subjected to high police presence.


He emphasised the need for all citizens to form neighborhood
watch groups that have been instrumental in combating crimes.


Last November, Home Affairs Minister Katele Kalumba declared a
war on criminals and warned that the country was at serious risk
of being over-run by criminals.


Meanwhile, in a bid to curb the crime wave, the Zambian
government last month offered a seven-day amnesty for people with
illegal firearms to surrender them to the police.


According to a Times of Zambia report, there are about 68,000
private guns in this landlocked African country with a comparatively
small population of 9.5 million.


Zambia has been experiencing in the past months more and more
aggravated robberies, murders and other serious crimes. The most
bizarre can be the killing of former finance minister Ronald
Penza in cold blood at his residence in early November.


The criminals, who used to be armed with knives, pangas, iron
bars or similar weapons and raided a house to steal some
property, now have evolved into organized crime groups.


They use modern military firearms and transport vehicles to
rob banks, snatch cars and loot filling stations in groups and in
broad daylight.


The capital city of Lusaka and the Copperbelt have been
identified as the most targeted areas.


Political observers here attributed the rampant crimes to the
bad economy which has been aggravated by lower employment, high
inflation, low or even negative gross national growth and rapid
devaluation of the local currency Kwacha.

results.content:
1997-04-06 
 China Allows Bigger Population Growth of Ethnic Groups 


HOHHOT, April 6 (Xinhua) -- The couples of minority groups in
China's vast northwestern regions are allowed to have a second or
even third child, unlike the majority Han group, and women of
child-bearing age are now being provided with better medical
treatment and other services in China's remote regions.


Chichige, a 38-year-old herdswoman in the Badain Jaran Desert
in Inner Mongolia, told Xinhua, "I had planned to have two
children. But, my first two children were girls who couldn't drive
the camels to do heavy work. So I had a third child -- a boy who
is now six years old."


She said the local government understood her difficulties and
when she was about to have her third child, they arranged for a
special medical team that drove more than 100 kilometers to her
house.


China adopted its one-child policy in the late 1970s to curb
the dramatic population growth, but eased family planning
restrictions for families of ethnic groups, even though family
planning was also advocated for better economic and cultural
development in ethnic areas and to improve the quality of their
lives.


Liu Zhilan, the director of the Family Planning Commission of
the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, said that the 48 ethnic
groups there include Mongolians, Huis, and Manchus, most of them
living in border areas that are sparsely populated and with a
harsh environment.


Inner Mongolia covers 1.18 million square kilometers, 12.3
percent of China's total landspace, and has a population of 23
million, which accounts for 1.8 percent of the nation's total. The
region's birth rate stands at 9.6 per thousand, lower than the
country's average.


Fifty years ago, the Mongolian population, the major ethnic
group there, had declined sharply. These people, with their
glorious history, had only 680,000 people when the autonomous
region was established in 1947.


The number of Mongolians came to 3.7 million, accounting for
15.8 of the region's total population, and the group's birth rate
was 20 per thousand. Other minority groups amounted to nearly
850,000 people and had a birth rate of 15 per thousand.


Liu said that since the early 1950s the central government has
sent a large number of medical personnel to the vast Inner
Mongolian grasslands to combat epidemic and infectious diseases
like plague and venereal disease. Quite a few Mongolian women who
had become infertile because of the venereal disease regained
their reproductive capacity after receiving treatment.


The Mongolian population has seen rapid growth in the past few
years and numbered 3.7 million by the end of 1996.


The nomadic life has meant that Mongolians tend to have fewer
children, and although their living conditions have greatly
improved, they still follow that tradition. However, the women of
other minority groups still expect to have more children.


Liu Zhilan, who has been involved in family planning for more
than 20 years, says that the regional government has focused on
improving the quality of life in the ethnic population rather than
curbing their numbers.


The region has several hundred schools and family planning
service centers for the nomadic population. Medical workers go by
horse or car for more than a hundred kilometers to provide medical
check-ups for pregnant women and family planning advice.


Liu says that more than 90 percent of the towns and villages
are even equipped with ultrasound equipment.

results.content:
1997-06-24 
 Song Jian on China's Implementation of Agenda 21 


UNITED NATIONS, June 23 (Xinhua) -- Chinese State Councillor
Song Jian told the U.N. Special Session on Environment today that
China has achieved great progress in the field of sustainable
development since the 1992 Earth Summit.


"I am glad to report to this Assembly that while registering
rapid economic growth in recent years, China has basically avoided
drastic environmental degradation and even registered some partial
improvement in the nation's environment," he said.


The U.N. Special Session on Environment comes five years after
the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro where 10,000 diplomats and
environmentalists outlined an ambitious blueprint to safeguard the
planet, which is later known as Agenda 21.


In a six-page speech to the Special Session, Song Jian outlined
six areas where China has gained progress by promoting sustainable
development according to Agenda 21:


-- Since the early 1990s, China's GNP has been growing at an
average annual rate of more than 10 percent and the
poverty-stricken population has declined from 80 million to 58
million at present;


-- Rapid population growth has been brought under control and
the nation's natural population growth rate has dropped steadily;


-- Notable achievements have been made in comprehensively
utilizing resources by promoting their conservation and by relying
on scientific and technological progress;


-- Efforts have been made to promote clean production
processes. The increase in discharged pollutants has been
effectively curbed by the closing down of 62,000 seriously
polluting enterprises;


-- More attention has been given to forest cultivation and a
nation-wide voluntary afforestation drive. Man-made forests now
cover 34.25 million hectares. Forest coverage increased from 12.98
percent in 1992 to 13.92 percent in 1996;


-- Greater efforts have been devoted to preserving
bio-diversity. A network of nature reserves has basically taken
shape, covering 71.85 million hectares or 7.2 percent of China's
total territory. Most of the endangered species are being
affectively protected.


Song told the assembly that these achievements have been scored
by the Chinese people and government by mainly relying on their
own efforts, which proves the effectiveness of China's policy of
integrating environmental and economic development.


In accordance with Agenda 21, he said, China took the lead to
formulate "China's Agenda 21," -- the White Paper on China's
Population, Environment and Development in the 21st Century, which
sets forth the guiding principles of holistic planning and
coordinated development of economy, society, resources and
environment.


Noting the severe environmental challenges China is still
faced, Song expressed optimism towards the future of the country
in accomplishing the goals of basically providing adequate food
and clothing to the poverty-stricken population by the end of the
century, achieving zero population growth around the year of 2030
and doing a good job in environmental protection.


"As the biggest developing country in the world, China will
contribute significantly to global environmental protection and
economic development by running her own affairs well," he said.
