results.content:
1997-07-24 
 China Not To Sacrifice Environment for Economic Growth: Premier (1) 


BEIJING, July 24 (Xinhua) -- Chinese Premier Li Peng said in a
speech published today that governments at various levels must
consistently adhere to the national policy of protecting the
environment for co-ordinated growth of the economy with the
environment and resources.


Li made the pledge at a national forum on family planning and
environmental protection held by the Chinese Communist Party
Central Committee on March 8. The full text of his speech was
released by Xinhua today.


"China must not follow the old road of `pollution control after
pollution,'" he said, stressing that it "should never sacrifice
the environment for temporary (economic) growth."


China's per capita arable land, water resources, forest and
many mineral resources are below the world's average, and the
current extensive mode of economic growth has further increased
waste and pollution, Li admitted.


Despite efforts and good results in curbing pollution and
waste, the general environmental quality has continued to
deteriorate, for the public's environmental awareness is still
weak, so is its ability to protect the environment, the premier
said.


"China still faces a heavy task to bring a fairly good
environment to the 21st century, together with an economy
maintaining sustainable, rapid and healthy growth," he said.


According to plan, China will, by the year 2000, basically
control environmental pollution and the tendency of ecological
deterioration and have the environmental quality in some cities
and areas improved.


To attain such goals, Premier Li listed the following
priorities for governments at all levels:


-- The urban environment must be put under strict control, with
the target of curbing industrial pollution.


Li said that urban atmospheric conditions in some cities have
become so bad that acid rain has emerged, and urban residents are
threaten by contaminated drinking water.

results.content:
ENERGY _ EVERYBODY WANTS MORE



   When you hear the term ``Big Oil,'' it conjures up images of
global behemoths such as Exxon-Mobil and Royal Dutch/Shell. It's
hard to imagine anybody kicking these multinational giants around.


   But American politicians and motorists regularly do. Whenever
gasoline prices shoot upward, as they have this year, Big Oil takes
it on the chin.


   For the most part, though, it's a bum rap. If Big Oil could
manipulate gas prices at will, as its critics infer, you wouldn't
see the precipitous price declines such as occurred in early 1999,
when the average U.S. pump price cratered to 99 cents a gallon.


   Energy prices are dictated primarily by powerful market forces
of supply and demand. They also can be affected by government
policies such as raising fuel taxes and by supply disruptions such
as pipeline breaks.


   The biggest sustained upward pressure on energy prices comes
from two factors largely ignored by politicians, consumers and the
news media: enormous worldwide population growth and growing energy
demand in developing countries where people are steadily buying
more cars, appliances and other energy-eating goods.


   After the oil price shocks of the late 1970s and early 1980s,
the world became more fuel-stingy. Cars, home heating and cooling
systems, and industrial operations became far more energy-efficient
in the wake of $35-a-barrel crude.


   But those efficiency gains have been more than offset by huge
population increases and rising worldwide energy consumption. Even
though global oil output has risen, demand has grown every bit as
fast.


   The world population hit 6 billion last fall, virtually double
the number when John F. Kennedy was elected president in 1960.


   In the last 12 years, another billion people have been added to
the planet. That increase is nearly four times the 275 million
people in the United States, the third most populous country in the
world (behind China, with 1.2 billion people, and India, with 1
billion).


   The U.S. Energy Information Administration has projected that
world energy consumption will jump by a staggering 60 percent from
1997 to 2020. Population gains and greatly heightened purchases of
energy-consuming goods in developing countries will be overwhelming
factors in this growth.


   While U.S. energy consumption is projected to rise 28 percent in
that period, the EIA forecasts that China will experience an
immense 265 percent increase and India a 231 percent jump.


   China is expected to be gobbling 9.5 million barrels of oil
every 24 hours in 2020 _ more than four times the 2.3 million
barrels it used daily in 1990.


   In 1997, only 10 Chinese in 1,000 owned cars; by 2020, 54 in
1,000 will _ a fivefold increase, the EIA forecasts.


   The EIA expects that the fossil fuels of oil, natural gas and
coal will still be the world's prime energy sources in 2020.


   The $64 question is how much impact a continued sharp rise in
global population and energy consumption will have not only on oil
and gasoline prices but in contributing to pollution and global
warming.


   Scott Tinker, director of the Bureau of Economic Geology at the
University of Texas in Austin, says of the prospects for
mushrooming energy use in large developing countries, ``It's a
scary thought when a billion people in India and well over a
billion people in China go through an industrial revolution.''


   Given all these ominous numbers, it's obvious that we must
accelerate the agenda for developing more fuel-efficient vehicles,
better mass transit systems, promising energy technologies such as
fuel cells, and improved means of curbing air pollution.


   We also should think much harder about whether we want to keep
adding another billion people to the globe every dozen years or so.


   (Jack Z. Smith is an editorial writer and columnist for the Fort
Worth Star-Telegram. He can be reached at (817) 390-7724 or
jzsmith(at)star-telegram.com. Visit the Star-Telegram's online
services on the World Wide Web: www.star-telegram.com)

results.content:
STUDY FORECASTS BEARISH TIMES FOR NEW YORK'S ECONOMY 



   ALBANY, N.Y. _ Wall Street's boom has artificially lifted New
York's economy and masked underlying weak job growth, particularly
in upstate New York, according to a study by a leading private
economic consulting firm.


   New York state's employment growth will be the slowest in the
nation from 1998 to 2002, at an average of 0.4 percent a year, the
Standard & Poor's DRI study said.


   The government quickly denounced the report.


   ``It's completely wrong,'' said Stephen Kagann, chief economist
for Gov. George Pataki. ``I'm surprised by it, stunned by it. I
can't believe they put this out.''


   Kagann said the number of new factories and businesses in New
York had soared in the last few years, which means there will be
even more jobs in the future.


   ``The turnaround in New York's economy is not a temporary
phenomenon,'' Kagann said.


   The Business Council of New York State Inc. said the report
failed to recognize the state's gains.


   The study by the Lexington, Mass.-based Standard & Poor's DRI
predicted an ``economic slowdown over the next five years'' brought
on by weak population growth and income gains harmed by job cuts in
manufacturing and commercial banking.


   As a result, the study said, limited demand for goods and
services will curb expansion of retail, service and real estate
markets. Kagann said that the next time the national economy turns
negative, New York will fare better than in the past because of tax
cuts.


   ``I expect that when we have the next national downturn, we will
do much, much better,'' he said.


   The study said the recent surge in stock market profits spurred
economic growth in metropolitan New York and boosted personal
income levels by 5.3 percent last year, including a record $10.2
billion in Wall Street bonuses.


   The study said that improvement led to last year's expansion in
consumer and retail trade, the largest percentage gain in total
employment since 1988 and a $1.8 billion state budget surplus.


   Nonetheless, the study said, the advances could be short-lived,
because New York's population is growing by 0.1 percent a year and
personal income growth is expected to be the eighth lowest in the
nation in the next few years.


   ``Financial services generates nearly 30 percent of New York's
gross state product,'' said Standard & Poor's economist Sara
Johnson, ``but the concentration of financial service companies in
New York City and Long Island makes the state uniquely vulnerable
to volatility in the U.S. securities market.''


   She said that even though New York has a diverse economy, its
dependence on financial services is risky in the short term.


   Business Council spokesman Robert Ward said that Wall Street,
while an inherently risky place, is only going to grow in the
future as more money continues to pour into stocks, especially if
Social Security privatizes some of its investments.


   But Ward said he agreed with the study's call for further tax
cuts and improvements in the business climate.


   The study said the state's high tax rates and uncompetitive
costs are driving out businesses.


   ``New York is now losing market share in every sector of the
economy,'' Johnson said.


   Johnson did praise Pataki's Republican administration for recent
economic policies.


   ``Fortunately, state government is addressing the high cost of
doing business by lowering corporate and property taxes,'' she
said. ``These initiatives should have a positive impact.''


   The study doesn't provide an unremittingly bleak view of New
York's economy. It says that New York will enjoy another year of
solid employment gains in 1998, about 1.4 percent growth.


   But it said employment growth will slow in the next few years
because of hits to commercial banking and manufacturing.

results.content:
CHECK THE FED'S PULSE. CALL US IN THE LONG TERM 



   James W. Paulsen, the chief investment officer at Wells Capital
Management in Minneapolis, says he is only tilting. Marshall Acuff,
the equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, is just moving at
the margin. And Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States
strategist at Lehman Brothers, is only trimming his expectations
for returns.


   These three strategists and others all had to review their
outlooks last week to accommodate the fact that the Federal Reserve
is now leaning toward raising its short-term interest rate target,
the federal funds rate.


   While no one knows when, or even if, the Fed will raise rates,
the policy makers have made it clear that if inflation does tick
up, they will move quickly.


   But according to these strategists, this bias toward higher
interest rates will not force them to make big changes in what they
have been doing.


   Even if the rally does not run wild, these analysts still expect
stocks to rise. Paulsen says the bond market will rally. Applegate
is betting that the Fed will not increase rates to slow growth and
curb inflation. Paulsen doesn't think the Fed will have to raise
rates _ though he says it is still a possibility. Acuff thinks any
rate increase will be modest.


   Paulsen has shifted his asset allocation slightly, to benefit
from the bond rally he expects when it becomes clear that inflation
will not get out of hand. So he is cutting his allocation to stocks
to 60 percent, from 70 percent, while raising bonds to 40 percent,
from 30 percent.


   ``I am not so negative on stocks,'' he said, explaining this
shift. ``I just think that bonds might meet them tick for tick.''


   He is also suggesting a small shift in the composition of stock
portfolios. He thinks economic growth will slow, partly because of
the rise in oil prices, the slower growth in real wages and the
slump in mortgage refinancings. All three will curb consumer
spending, which has been the driving force of the economy's still
rapid growth.


   For Paulsen, a slowdown makes growth stocks, especially the
big-name companies that can produce solid earnings in a weaker
economy, attractive again. He also likes financial stocks, which
will benefit from declining market rates, and consumer staples,
which also do well in a slower-growth environment.


   But that does not mean he is dumping all his cyclical stocks,
which have done very well this year. ``I believe you should tilt in
the direction you think the market is going,'' Paulsen said. ``But
I am not selling all my cyclicals. I known I can be wrong.''


   Applegate is also shifting out of cyclicals and into growth
stocks. ``The cyclical trade has come and gone,'' he said. But he
is holding his asset allocation at 80 percent stocks and 20 percent
bonds.


   The recent rise in interest rates has curbed the expansion in
valuations that would help stocks move higher, he said, but
corporate earnings forecasts are improving. His firm just raised
its 1999 operating earnings forecast to 10 percent, from 8 percent.
His year-end target for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is
unchanged at 1,450, 9 percent above Friday's close.


   And Applegate would not think of trying to shift out of stocks
to sidestep a slump. He did not even do that last year, when the
major market indexes plunged 19 percent or more, because he worried
that he would not get back in quickly enough.


   Why so sanguine? Because there is confidence that the Fed will
not let inflation get out of hand, which means that the long-term
still looks fine. And because the investing environment had, in
fact, changed long before the Fed announcement.


   Investors had worried most of this year about a Fed rate
increase because the economy refused to slow down. The jump in
long-term interest rates by a percentage point, to 5.92 percent
since December, was a result.

said, ``If you have been an investor paying attention, there was no

results.content:
1996-02-12 12:01 
 Ramos Urges Balance of Food, Population Growth 


MANILA, February 12 (Xinhua) -- President Fidel Ramos today
called on all countries to "strike a synergistic balance between
the three development factors of population, resources and
environment."


Ramos made the remarks in his keynote address before the 12th
Asian parliamentarians meeting on population and development which
started here today.


The president said the widening gap between food supplies and
population growth is an ominous daily threat to millions around
the world.


He emphasized the need to curb high population growth,
especially in Asia, in a bid to concentrate resources for
improvement of people's life.


"Quite clearly, we cannot long afford the effects of this steep
population growth rate and the highly vulnerable condition of our
natural resources and environment," he added.


According to him, for the first time the Asia Pacific Economic
Cooperation (APEC) recognizes food, human resource development and
population as key issues to sustained economic growth.


He said that his government considers population management as
an important factor towards achieving food security and
development.


The two-day meeting was organized by the Asian Population and
Development Association and the Philippine Legislators' Committee
on Population and Development Foundation, in cooperation with the
Philippine Senate.

results.content:
1996-10-15 
 Mozambican Population Reaches 18 Million 


MAPUTO, October 14 (Xinhua) -- Mozambique's population has
reached 18 million, according to the National Statistics Bureau
(NSB) today.


NSB director Fonseca Machaule told a news conference that the
country's population is expected to arrive at 20 million with the
current annual growth rate of 2.6%.


The official said the rapid growth of population has blocked
the economic development of Zimbabwe which is faced with the
challenges of increasing illiteracy, curbed forest and cultivated
land, lack of housing, shortage of food as well as an
deteriorated environment.

results.content:
2000-03-09 
 Zambian Government Urged to Curb Crocodile Growth 


LUSAKA, March 9 (Xinhua) -- A Zambian village headman, whose
daughter was killed by a crocodile recently, Thursday appealed to
the government to curb the growth of crocodile population in the
Zambezi river.


The headman told Zambia News Agency in Mongu, the capital of
Western province, that the Zambezi river, which stretches for
1,520 kilometres in the country, has become infested with
crocodiles.


The headman urged the government to take actions or else more
people and cattle would be killed by the reptiles.


He said his daughter, 39, was killed by a crocodile last month
as she was washing clothes in the Zambezi river.


Another woman from the same village narrowly escaped last
January after a crocodile missed her by a flicker as she drew
water from the same river at almost the same spot.

results.content:
1997-04-12 
 Women's Illiteracy Blamed for Over-Population in 


LAGOS, April 12 (Xinhua) -- The high level of illiteracy among
the Nigerian women has been identified as the major factor
responsible for the over-population in the country, the New
Nigerian reported today.


The government-owned newspaper quoted a bank official as
saying that a greater percentage of the Nigerian women are still
illiterate and do not know how to effectively and adequately plan
their family size.


David Drumm of the First City Merchant Bank made the
disclosure at the 20th anniversary lecture of the Nigeria-British
Chamber of Commerce here at the weekend.


But he didn't give any figure to show the percentage.


He warned that if nothing was done to curb this situation, the
Nigerian population in the next 22 years would be twice the
current figure, while Lagos would become the third most populous
city in the world.


According to statistics, Nigeria now has a population of 102
million (the United Nations puts it at 115 million), compared
with some 88 million in 1991.


To curb the fast population growth, Drumm said, there was an
urgent need for the Nigerian government to pay greater attention
to the education of women while measures such as rural areas
development had become necessary to check rural-urban shift.


What Nigeria needs most are engineers and technicians,
according to the banker.

results.content:
1996-06-05 
 News Analysis: Pakistan Endeavors to Curb Child Labor 


ISLAMABAD, June 5 (Xinhua) -- The Pakistani government is
taking a series of measures to curb child labor, a growing social
problem facing many developing nations.


The government is now taking an unprecedented nationwide survey
on child labor, which is expected to be completed soon.


Relatively low economic growth and an increasingly exploding
population are believed to be the main reasons for the child labor
problem in the country.


Pakistan, with a population of approximately 130 million at
present, is already the world's seventh most populous country, and
with an annual growth rate of about 3 percent, it will rank fifth
by the year 2020 when its total population is projected to reach
262 million.


However, the gross national product (GNP), which is running at
an annual growth rate of 3 to 6 percent in recent years, can not
be well-matched with the growth of the country's population. As an
immediate result, more people live in poverty.


According to local media reports, about one third of the
population in Pakistan still live under the poverty line, and the
country's child laborers are numbered at about eight million.


As an active way to save children from hard labor and send them
back to school, the Pakistani government has mapped out a strategy
to develop primary education countrywide, especially in rural and
under-developed urban areas.


To help raise the national education level, Prime Minister
Benazir Bhutto has promised to make it a law that 3 percent of the
GNP be allocated to the education sector annually.


Meanwhile, the government is taking every possible steps to
control the country's population, and elaborate arrangements are
being made in this regard under the eighth five-year plan.


Official statistics show that there are 45,000 villages in
Pakistan with a total population of 85 million. More than 13,060
of these villages have a population of 2,000 each.


Under the government plan, in every such village, an educated
married woman, who belongs to the village concerned, will be
selected and employed on contract basis to spread the message of
family planning.


Moreover, to provide more educational facilities and
opportunities to school-age children, a number of laws and other
related measures have been adopted by the government and
non-governmental organizations.


As an initial step, children under the age of 14 are not
allowed to work in high intensity, poisonous or dangerous
industries, such as carpet-weaving, cement, explosive
manufacturing, dyeing, construction and transportation.


Concerned laws also provide detailed regulations on the timing,
safety and health standards for adolescent workers and increased
penalties for those breaking the laws.


In the past year alone, the government conducted nearly 3,000
inspections, resulting in prosecutions in about 1,000 cases.


Meanwhile, several government organizations, such as the
National Committee on the Rights of the Child, the Pakistan
Commission, have been set up to take care of children's rights,
welfare and development.


Some non-governmental organizations, with the help of the
government, have planned to set up 35 rehabilitation centers for
children in areas where child labor are concentrated.


These centers will be responsible for imparting primary
education and vocational training to the children.


However, to eliminate child labor is not the work of a single
day. Observers here believe that despite all these efforts, the
Pakistani government is still facing a Herculean task in this
regard.


More efforts are needed to develop economy, control population
growth and spread education for an eventual solution of the
problem.

results.content:
1996-08-04 
 Bangladesh Seeks WB Aid for Poverty Alleviation 


DHAKA, August 4 (Xinhua) -- The Bangladeshi government has
sought aid from the World Bank for poverty alleviation through
promoting universal education and curbing the population growth.


In a meeting with the visiting director of the World Bank's
South Asian Region, Mieko Nishimizo on Saturday, Bangladeshi Prime
Minister Shiekh Hasina said, "We are looking forward to assistance
from the World Bank in this regard."


She said her government had given top priority to poverty
alleviation through spread of education and downsizing the
population growth.


"Things cannot be done overnight and it will take time for us
as we have inherited a legacy of the last 21 years," Hasina added.

results.content:
1998-03-15 
 Jiang Stresses Family Planning, Environmental Protection (1) 


BEIJING, March 15 (Xinhua) -- President Jiang Zemin today vowed
to curb environmental deterioration in the coming 15 years and
bring an obviously better ecological appearance to the country in
another 15 years.


The ongoing reshuffle inside governmental bodies at all levels
must not weaken or even affect the efforts of family planning and
environmental protection, Jiang said at a high-profile meeting
concerning the country's work on family planning and environmental
protection.


"Family planning and environmental protection are of vital
importance to sustainable economic growth while having a bearing
on the existence and development of our next generations," Jiang
said.


"It is a significant endeavor for us, not only in this century
but also in the coming 21st century," Jiang said.


China has met the goals of controlling population growth for
eight straight years, he noted.


The country also had a low rate of birth, death and population
growth, he added.


Many local authorities have closed down small businesses which
consumed too much energy and produced heavy pollution.
 In addition, the environment near the Huaihe River has improved
after pollution-check efforts in recent years, he noted.


However, family planning and environmental protection are
strenuous and long-time jobs, he added. The country has a jumbo
population and a poor environment, which cannot be changed in a
short period, Jiang said.


The population growth has yet to be controlled in rural areas,
he said.


Furthermore, ecological disturbances and environmental
pollution still remain a factor in many areas, he said, even some
undergoing hazardous environmental deterioration, he said.

results.content:
1999-07-10 
 Government Urges People to Control Population 


NEW DELHI, July 10 (Xinhua) -- On the eve of World Population
Day, Indian caretaker Health and Family Welfare Minister Dalit
Ezhilmalai in a message here Saturday called upon the people in
the country to make joint efforts to achieve population
stabilization in the country.


With the current annual population growth rate of 1.86 percent,
Indian population is expected to cross one billion by the first
quarter of the year 2000, he said.


The minister asked all government agencies, private sector and
non-governmental organizations to work together in disseminating
the small-family message to help curb population rise.


The minister will flag off a population race here Sunday and
about 5,000 school children and 1,000 volunteers of Sports
Authority of India will participate in the race.

results.content:
1996-04-20 
 Africa Sees Economic Achievements in 1995 


ABIDJAN, April 20 (Xinhua) -- Africa's foreign trade volume
reached a record high in 1995 accompanied by the lowest inflation
level for four years, the African Development Bank (ADB) said in
its latest report.


But the bank also warned the continent faces major challenges,
including combating poverty, increasing agricultural production
to feed a growing population and curbing foreign debt.


Africa registered a record 210 billion U.S. dollars of foreign
trade volume in 1995, including 111.7 billion dollars of imports,
and 98.5 billion dollars of exports, up 13.5 percent and 11.8
percent respectively over 1994, the report said.


African countries successfully curbed inflation in 1995, with
the average inflation rate down from 42 percent in 1994 to 26.6
percent, the lowest level in the past four years. Of the 53
African nations, Sechelles had the lowest inflation rate of 0.18
percent in 1995.


In another sign of their improving financial situation, African
countries reduced the proportion of their budget deficits from an
average of 5.1 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1994 to
an average of 3.3 percent in 1995.


The overall GDP in Africa also grew by a record 2.9 percent in
1995. Economic growth rates in Kenya, Egypt, Uganda, Ethiopia,
Ghana and Cote d'Ivoire all exceeded 4 percent.


The manufacturing and processing industries have become
increasingly vital to economic development and to increased
exports, especially in South Africa, Egypt, Kenya and Zimbabwei,
the report said.


The Abidjan-based bank attributed these achievements to a
relatively stable political situation and strengthened regional
cooperation.


But the report also listed several challenges to economic
revitalization in Africa, which is home to 700 million people,
half of them living in abject poverty.


In some countries, it said, destabilizing political situations
still exist and corruption prevails among government officials.


The growth of per capita agricultural production in 1995, at 2
percent, still lags behind the continent's population growth rate,
and foreign debts continue to increase in Africa, reaching a
staggering 320.4 billion dollars, it said.


Moreover, the report added, most African countries remain
highly dependent on external markets, funds and technology.

results.content:
1997-02-09 
 Sichuan Collects Record Amount of Taxes in 1996 


CHENGDU, February 9 (Xinhua) -- Sichuan Province, China's most
populous province with over 100 million people, collected more
than 14.1 billion yuan (about 1.7 billion US dollars) in local
taxes in 1996, an over-30-percent increase compared to the
previous year.


The annual growth rate was more than 10 percentage points
higher than the national average, according to an official of the
local tax bureau.


The official attributed the significant growth mainly to
greater efforts to collect taxes and curb tax evasion.


He added that a provincial taxation check last year covered
139,000 taxpayers, netting 216 million yuan in what would
otherwise have been tax losses.

results.content:
2000-02-16 
 UNFP Allocates $13.7M to Ethiopia for Medical Services 


ADDIS ABABA, February 16 (Xinhua) -- The United Nations Fund
for Population (UNFP) has allocated 13.7 million U.S. dollars to
Ethiopia this year to improve reproductive health and family
planning services in the country, a UNFP official said here
Wednesday.


UNFP representative Benson Morah told media that 11 million
dollars of the allocated fund would be applied to reproductive
health and the rest for raising public awareness.


The stated amount is part of the 30 million dollars the UNFP
has set aside for the execution of population-related projects in
Ethiopia since 1980, Benson said.


Family planning services are bearing fruits in Ethiopia, he
said, adding that the UNFP would continue to work with the
Ethiopian government to curb the spread of HIV/AIDS in the Horn of
Africa country.


According to the statistics released by the Ethiopian National
Population Office, the annual population growth rate of the
country has dropped to 2.9 percent from 3.2 percent. Currently,
Ethiopia has a population of 62 million.

results.content:
CONFERENCE OFFERS CONTROVERSIAL PROPOSALS TO CURB POPULATION
GROWTH 



   UNITED NATIONS _ Unrestricted access to safe abortions in
countries were it is legal, education in ``sexual and reproductive
health issues'' at all school levels, and confidential
contraceptive advice to ``sexually active adolescents'' _ these are
among the more controversial recommendations presented Friday by a
179-nation conference called to review progress made on goals set
five years ago to curb the world's population growth.


   The 1994 Cairo agreement on population and development had
called for freezing the total population at no more than 9.8
billion in the year 2050. It is currently 6 billion.


   Despite objections towards these and certain other
recommendations from a small group of conservative Muslim and Roman
Catholic countries, backed by the Vatican, the conference adopted
them by consensus as part of a new action plan approved Friday for
reaching the Cairo population goals. Argentina, Nicaragua and the
Vatican filed reservations.


   Population officials generally expressed satisfaction with the
meeting's outcome. ``Cairo has taken root and is working'' the
chief U.S. delegate, Undersecretary of State Frank Loy, said at a
closing press conference Friday.


   Rather than merely setting numerical targets and mounting
family-planning campaigns, the Cairo strategy for limiting
population growth seeks to improve the status of women in the
belief that they will then have smaller families.


   This week's conference recommended that governments make a
number of adjustments to this strategy mainly in the way they treat
abortion, the 1.1 billion people in the world between the ages of
15 and 24 and the estimated 33 million people infected with the
AIDS virus.


   It urged governments to deal resolutely with the damage done to
women by unskilled abortionists, saying that where this practice is
legal they should ``train and equip health-service providers and
should take other measures to insure that abortion is safe and
accessible.''


   While Chile and El Salvador are the only countries to ban
abortion outright, another 75 or so only permit it only when a
woman's life is directly threatened.


   The 1994 Cairo action plan called simply for abortion to be
``safe'' in countries where it is legal. It did not say abortions
should be ``accessible'' or make governments responsible for
insuring practitioners are qualified.


   Almost equally contentious, however, were the conference's
recommendations dealing with young people. It called for school
children, at all levels, to be instructed in ``sexual and
reproductive health issues'' in order to teach them ``responsible
sexual behavior'' and protect them from ``unwanted pregnancy'' and
sexually transmitted diseases.


   It also told governments to provide ``special family-planning
information, counseling and health services'' for ``sexually active
adolescents'' and to help them avoid AIDS.


   While governments should respect ``the rights, duties and
responsibilities of parents'' as well as ``cultural values and
religious beliefs,'' the conference said they should ``safeguard
the right of adolescents to privacy, confidentiality and informed
consent'' when providing such assistance.


   These new recommendations go far beyond those of Cairo, which
simply asked governments to provide adolescents with ``guidance in
sexual and reproductive matters'' and not to restrict their access
to ``appropriate services and the advice they need.''


   Once again, conservative governments sought to emphasize
parents' right to control all aspects of their children's education
and to play down the state's role in making sex education and
contraceptive advice available to young people.


   The conference also recognized that the AIDS pandemic is far
worse now than expected five years ago by setting new, specific
targets for reducing the infection's spread.


   By 2005, it said, governments should insure that at least 90
percent of adolescents have access to ``the information, education
and services n

results.content:
1999-09-12 
 Nigeria Calls for Int'l Help in Population Control 


LAGOS, September 12 (Xinhua) -- Nigeria's Health Minister Tim
Menakaya has urged international agencies to assist the country to
curb its fast growing population and to implement its poverty
alleviation strategies.


At Saturday's inauguration ceremony of a fund generation
committee of the Population Activities Fund (PAF) which took place
in Abuja, Menakaya stressed that with the current annual growth
rate of 2.83 percent, the population is expected to reach 235.6
million by the year 2025.


The Guardian, a leading Nigerian newspaper, Sunday quoted him
as saying " Nigeria, with an estimated population of 110 million,
is the most populous country in Africa and among the thirteen
poorest countries in the world. The Federal Ministry of Health
will implement key strategies which include fertility reduction,
maternal and child survival, improvement in the status of women,
creation of awareness on need for small family size and poverty
alleviation."


Lamenting the discouraging flow of financial assistance from
international donor agencies, the minister said, "the Official
Development Assistance declined from $61 billion in 1992 to 47.6
billion U.S. dollars in 1997."

results.content:
1999-04-16 
 U.N. Hails U.S. Congressional Committee's Vote to 


UNITED NATIONS, April 16 (Xinhua) -- The United Nations
Population Fund (UNFPA) welcomed a vote of 23-17 by the U.S. House
of Representatives International Relations Committee to restore
American funding of the U.N. agency, which was stopped in
September 1998, U.N. officials said Friday.


UNFPA Executive Director NAfis Sadik welcomed the renewed
commitment by Members of Congress to restore funding, saying "the
United States has always been a leader in the population field and
played an important role in global family planning efforts."


The amendment to the Foreign Relations Authorization Act, which
was passed Wednesday, received bipartisan support by members of
Congress who argued that the U.S. should support UNFPA, which
plays a critical role in protecting women's health and curbing
population growth. The full House of Representatives is expected
to vote on the amendment next week.


As passed, the amendment would authorize a contribution of 25
million U.S. dollars to UNFPA in fiscal year 2000 and 25 million
U.S. dollars in 2001 under a strict set of conditions.

results.content:
1997-09-07 
 Higher Input Prices, Misuse of Fertilizer Hurt 


DHAKA, September 7 (Xinhua) -- Input price hikes and haphazard
use of fertilizers are hurting Bangladesh's agriculture and the
government should take measures to ensure the efficient
application of technology in the sector, a local newspaper said
today.


Agriculture is the mainstay of the South Asian country's
economy and it accounts for about 37 percent of the GDP, though
that share will decline as industrial incomes and employment rise.


The agriculture's development, however, is now being curbed by
input price hikes, unplanned use of chemical fertilizers and
insecticides in farmland as well as inefficiency in applying
technology, the Independence newspaper said.


With the overwhelming majority of the population -- 87
percent-- living in the rural areas, and over half of them living
below the poverty line, no growth and poverty alleviation strategy
for Bangladesh can succeed without a healthy agricultural sector,
the newspaper stressed.


A special study report of the World Bank entitled "Bangladesh:
Agenda for Action, 1996" underlines the fact that the vast
majority of the Bangladesh population depend on agriculture and
natural resources for a large part of their food and incomes, the
paper noted.


The Bangladeshi government has already given serious attention
to the grave situation in the agriculture and its budgetary
allocations had been made to subsidize the agricultural sector,
the paper said.


What is needed more urgently appears to be applying appropriate
and affordable technologies to ensure sustainable growth of the
sector, the newspaper said.

1999-09-08 
 Ethiopia to Make Demographic, Health Survey Next 


ADDIS ABABA, September 7 (Xinhua) -- Ethiopia is to launch a
demographic and health survey (DHS) early next year, the first of
its kind in the country, the Central Statistics Authority (CSA)
announced here Tuesday.


Addressing a seminar, CSA General Manager Abdulahi Hassen said
reliable socio-economic and demographic data are important factors
in any development planning.


The DHS is a national sample survey designed to provide
information on levels and trends of fertility, infant and child
mortality, family planning as well as maternal and child health,
Abdulahi said.


The planned survey will be financed by the United States Agency
for International Development, the United Nations Population Fund
and the Ethiopian government.


The questionnaires will be conducted in 540 sample sites, with
14,300 women aged between 15 and 49 to be interviewed in randomly
selected households, Abdulahi said.


Ethiopia, with a population of 60 million at an annual growth
rate of 3. 5 percent, has been making efforts to curb increasing
population in the country, he said.

"The critical success factor in becoming competitive in the new
global economy rests with our ability to harness knowledge into

COLOMBO -- Sri Lanka recorded a 6.9 percent growth rate in
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) terms during the first half of this
year due to buoyant exports, according to provisional estimates.


"The annual growth rate appears to be somewhat higher than the
original estimate of 5.5 percent of the Central Bank. It is now
estimated to be in the region of six percent," a highly placed
Central Bank source was quoted as saying by the Sunday Observer
here.  (Sri Lanka-GDP)

LUSAKA -- For fear of further swelling its external debt burden,
Malawi has rejected a loan of 40 million U.S. dollars from World
Bank (WB) aimed at curbing the further spread of HIV/AIDS in the
country, Zambia's Sunday Mail newspaper reported on Sunday.


It quoted the country's Deputy Health Minister Philip Bwanali
as saying the loan was offered during the recent health and
finance ministers' AIDS summit in Nairobi, Kenya.  (Malawi-WB-
Loan)

CAIRO -- Egypt's population reached 65.205 million at the start
of 2000, indicating a growth rate of 2.02 percent in 1999,
according to census results announced on Sunday.


One baby was born every 24.4 seconds on average during the past
three years in the country, Director of Egypt's Central Agency of
Public Mobilization and Statistics Ihab Elawi told a press
conference.  (Egypt-Population)

results.content:
Falling birthrate of Africa, THE INDEPENDENT


WASHINGTON, D.C. 20003 Tel: 202-547-4512 Fax: 202-546-4194
COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC.
AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN
MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
	   Africa is making substantial headway in curbing its birthrate,
but still faces major challenges such as reducing teenage
pregnancy, according to a latest study by a major US population
research group. To sustain and accelerate progress, donor nations
should double their assistance for family planning and related
health care from the present total of 500 million dollars, to at
least one billion dollars by the year 2000, according to the report
by Population Action International (PAI).
	   The 82-page report, Population Challenge,' argues that the
region's prospects for economic development largely depend on the
success governments can achieve in reducing the birth rate and
providing better health care to mothers and children. 'Africa is a
latecomer to the revolution in reproductive behaviour sweeping
across the developing world, but is now poised for positive change
with respect to childbearing patterns and sexual health,'' says
Shanti Conly, co-author of the study. She adds pointedly 'The needs
are urgent...''Sub-Saharan Africa's population - the fastest
growing in the world - effectively doubled in the last quarter
century to 620 million and could double again in less than 30
years.
	   For more than a generation, population growth of almost three
percent per year generally has outpaced economic growth - until the
last few years. As a result, Africans' per capita income is about
22 percent below what it was in 1975. According to the report,
however, African governments increasingly have taken steps to
address these problems. About two- thirds of the countries in the
region now have active family-planning programmes. A fundamental
shift in people's attitudes toward child-bearing has become
increasingly evident, the report says. This shift is explained in
part by increasing economic hardship for poor families who, given
government budget cuts, find it more difficult to afford the costs
of educating more children.

 Major News Items in Leading Philippine Newspapers 


MANILA, July 24 (Xinhua) -- The following are major news items
in leading Philippine newspapers today:


Manila Bulletin


-- President Ramos said Wednesday the peso is stabilizing and
prices of basic commodities have been stable despite the recent
peso depreciation.


The Philippine Star


-- President Ramos called Wednesday for a stepped-up campaign
to curb population growth, saying birth control was the only
viable way to reduce poverty.


The Business Daily


-- The Central Bank of the Philippines has temporarily
tightened its grip on dollar holdings by banks for a period of 90
days in a bid to minimize opportunities for speculative plays in
the foreign exchange market.

 Major News Items in Leading Philippine Newspapers

in leading Philippine newspapers Sunday.


Manila Bulletin:


-- Philippine President Joseph Estrada Saturday named Lt. Gen.

results.content:
1997-07-19 
 Consumer Price Index Goes up in Angola's Capital 


LUANDA, July 18 (Xinhua) -- The National Statistics Bureau of
Angola announced here today that the consumer price index in
Luanda region increased by 0.55 percent from May to June.


According to figures released here today, the prices of
clothing and footwear increased by a biggest margin, or 4.15
percent from May to June, which was followed by food, drinks and
tobacco by 0.21 percent.


For the first half of this year, the consumer price index has
risen 11.4 percent, with housing, fuel and power soaring by a
biggest margin, at 1,646 percent, and food, drinks and
tobacco at a lowest margin, or 1.98 percent.


Luanda region with a population of four million which accounts
for one-third of the country's population is the biggest consumer
market and also regarded as the barometer of the national
economy.


Compared with last year, the consumer index has slowed down
its pace of growth because the measures taken by the government
to curb inflation has taken effect.

results.content:
1999-03-18 
 Water, Soil Conservation Project Going Well in Gansu 


LANZHOU, March 18 (Xinhua) -- A World Bank-financed project has
brought soil erosion under control in a large part of the Malian
River Valley in northwest China's Gansu Province.


The Malian River Valley covers an area of 4,304 square
kilometers on the middle reaches of the Yellow River, and has a
population of 508,000. Serious soil erosion had caused
agricultural conditions to deteriorate until 1994, when a loan of
69.64 million U.S. dollars, including 40 million U.S. dollars from
the World Bank, was utilized for a project, which curbed this
trend toward ecological imbalance.


Water and soil conservation now has returned to normal in more
than 60 percent of the Malian River Valley land, and trees and
grass now cover more than 30 percent of its total acreage, local
authorities said.


This effort greatly spurred the growth of the local economy,
and the valley's poor population had been reduced to 18.5 percent
of the total by the end of last year, from 40 percent in 1994.

results.content:
1998-08-11 
 Sevilla Elects Quito Mayor 


QUITO, August 10 (Xinhua) -- Roque Sevilla was elected mayor of
Quito by the city council Monday to fill the vacancy left by Jamil
Mahuad, who was sworn in as the new president of the Republic on
the same day.


In his inauguration speech, Sevilla vowed to curb the city's
population growth, air and water pollution, while improving the
infrastructure for a more prosperous capital city during his
two-year tenure, which expires on August 10, 2000.


Sevilla, an assistant in the city government led by Mahuad, was
elected by a majority of votes by 15 people's representatives in
the council on Monday.


The new president, in his farewell speech as a mayor, thanked
the people in Quito for what he called "unconditional support"
during his term.

results.content:
1996-11-16 
 S.African Finance Minister Warns of Growing Debt 


JOHANNEBURG, November 16 (Xinhua) -- Debt would become the
single largest item in South Africa's budget unless it was curbed
in time, Finance Minister Trevor Manuel was quoted by today's
"the Citizen" as warning.


Addressing the annual congress of the Federation of South
African Labour Unions on Friday in Pretoria, Manuel said the
country's debt would be 311 billion Rand (about 66 billion US
Dollars) by the end of the current fiscal year, in comparison
with that of 20 billion Dollars in 1989.


Debt service has taken 36 billion Rand (about 7.8 billion US
Dollars) off the budget of this year, according to the minister.


"Unless checked, debt will become the single largest item in
the budget," Manuel warned.


The Minister blamed the former apartheid government for the
excesses, saying the new government inherited a state which saw
its mandate as primarily dealing with a minority of the
population.


Between 1975 and 1983, the apartheid regime spent some 32.5
million US Dollars on the security establishment only, said
Manuel.


He also admitted that the country had an annual population
growth of about 2.4 percent between 1980 and 1993, while the
economy was shrinking at 0.2 percent a year.

results.content:
1997-10-17 
 Indonesia Calls for End to Food Disparity 


JAKARTA, October 17 (Xinhua) -- Indonesian President Soeharto
has appealed to the world community to join hands to curb food
shortages, improve food quality and provide a secure food supply
for all nations.


"On the whole, total world food output could meet the
consumption needs of the global population, even exceed them,"
Soeharto noted when speaking at the commemoration of the 17th
World Food Day here Thursday.


"But there is a disparity in food supply. On one hand, the
advanced industrialized countries have a food surplus. On the
other hand, the poor developing countries face an acute food
shortage, forcing them to import food to feed their people," he
noted. "This disparity should be mended."


He said the world community should realize that food supply is
still a major international problem. "Hunger, food shortage and
malnutrition continue to haunt many nations of the world."


He called on developed and developing countries to cooperate in
increasing the food resilience defense and reducing food crisis in
what he called the free trade era.


Entering the 21st century, he pointed out, food supply will
face various challenges including population growth, urbanization
and the changing pattern of food consumption and the food
technology.


Quoting U.N. data, the president said some 800 million of the
world population are suffering food shortage and critical
nutrition problem, of whom some 200 million are children under
five years old.

results.content:
2000-04-21 
 China Ready to Enact Inheritance Tax 


BEIJING, April 21 (Xinhua) -- China is now ready to enact the
inheritance tax, a senior tax expert said here today.


Deputy director of the Taxation Science Research Institute
under the State Administration of Taxation (SAT) Liu Zuo told
Xinhua that the time is ripe to start collecting inheritance taxes.


From the founding of New China in 1949 until 1990, China twice
introduced the inheritance tax, but failed to actually collect it.


Liu said that things have changed greatly over the past decade
with rapid economic growth, and the per capita income of the
Chinese people is now more than 20 times of that of 40 years ago.
The gap of income disparity has also widened. Some 20 percent of
the population now holds more than 80 percent of all savings
deposits in the country.


Liu said that the current economic situation also requires
that the government narrow the gap between rich and poor in order
to maintain social stability and stimulate consumption.


The aim of the inheritance tax is to curb the excessive growth
of wealth among a small group of individuals, re-distribute social
wealth, and increase fiscal revenues.


Since the awareness of taxation is growing in China, the
revenue from individual income tax also has been growing at a
double-digit rate over the past few years.


In order to create sound conditions for levying the inheritance
tax, the government has imposed real name requirements on bank
savings accounts, and is developing a standardized notary system.


Liu said that only the richest one to three percent of the
population will be subject to the tax, and the taxable part of an
individual's inheritance will include both movable and immovable
assets. The rate of this inheritance tax may be as high as 50
percent, he said.


He said that income tax, property tax, and inheritance tax all
will become important leverages in the governments attempt to
adjust individual incomes.

results.content:
1998-08-06 11:39 
 Efforts Urged to Curb Thalassemia Disease in Jordan 


AMMAN, August 6 (Xinhua) -- Jordanian experts have urged the
government to make more efforts to curb the spread of thalassemia
disease, which affected 12 percent of the kingdom's 4 million
population, the Jordan Times reported Thursday.


"This is an alarming issue that should be taken seriously,"
said Nayef Gharaybeh, director of the Health Center at the
University of Science and Technology, who has been conducting
study on thalassemia for years.


Patients of this disease, common in Mediterranean countries,
suffer from hemolytic anemia due to the destruction of the red
blood cells. They are sick and pale and obsessed with enlarged
spleens and delayed growth.


Gharaybeh found that the disease's inheritability, intertwined
with the popular consanguineous marriage in Jordan, contributed to
the current situation.


He noted that the often case is that not a single member, but
many members in one family are thalamessia carriers.


The Ministry of Health and Medical Care spends an average of 3
million Jordanian dinars (about 4.2 million U.S. dollars) each
year on treating some 1,000 patients who visited hospitals for
treatment of thalamessia.


Individual carriers of thalamessia are relatively healthy, but
when they become parents there is 25 percent possibility that any
child they have will inherit this disease, said Gharaybeh.


Mustafa Al Falah, a haematologist at the state-run Al Bashir
Hospital, told the Jordan Times that a thalamessia child becomes
anaemic at between three and 18 months of age. If they are not
treated, they usually die.


The Jordanian government has been advocating pre-marital tests
in order to prevent the spread of thalamessia and other
genetically-transmitted diseases, but the effect was limited.


Would-be couples usually hesitate to accept such tests, because
of social taboos and the fear that the tests could expose
infertility-related problems that might scuttle their marriage
plans.

results.content:
1999-02-06 
 Backgrounder: U.N. to Step up Efforts to Stabilize  Global Population 


UNITED NATIONS, February 5 (Xinhua) -- The United Nations
Population Fund (UNFPA) has organized a five-day "Hague Forum,"
scheduled for Monday in the Netherlands, with delegates from 180
nations.


The upcoming forum was designed to evaluate progress since a
landmark 1994 conference in Cairo, the third such global meeting
since 1974 and the one that switched directions from an emphasis
on demographic control to general health care, education and
choice as part of a family planning approach to curbing population
growth.


UNFPA argues that if women were literate, informed and able to
make their own decisions, they would choose to have fewer
children. Such action was needed to reduce poverty and hunger and
to protect the earth's natural resources.


Since alarm bells sounded some 30 years ago about the dangers
of an overcrowded planet, world leaders have initiated a panoply
of programmes to slow the population explosion.


But it will take at least another 50 years before the world's
population, now at 5.9 billion, will begin to stabilize at 8.9
billion people, bringing monumental problems for poor nations in
the interim, according to U.N. experts planning a forum next week
in The Hague, Netherlands.


Alternatively, if programmes falter and money to finance them
remains scarce, the world could have 10.7 billion people by 2050.


"In short, the planet seems to have averted -- at least for now
-- the threat of a population bomb. The danger now is that we will
declare victory and go home," says the U.N. Population Fund
(UNFPA).


However, direct U.S. funding to countries for family planning
programmes was 540 million U.S. dollars in 1995, before being
slashed by the U.S. Congress to its present level of 385 million
U.S. dollars, about a third of the goal.


But Nafis Sadik, the Pakistani physician who heads UNFPA, noted
that Washington was not alone in failing to meet targets promised
in Cairo, where nations agreed to increase spending on population
programmes and related projects to 17 billion U.S. dollars by 2000
and 22 billion U.S. dollars by 2015.


One third was to come from rich nations and in 1995 industrial
states met their targets. But since then most have reduced support
for population measures except for Denmark, Finland, Sweden,
Norway and the Netherlands.

results.content:
1996-01-26 07:20 
 "People's Daily" Refutes Containment of China Bid (2) 


In the wake of the steady development of worldwide and regional
integrated economic co-operation in recent years, China's economy
has become an important component of the world economy and
interwound with the latter, the article said.


China recorded a total foreign trade value of 280 billion US
dollars in 1995 and the amount of foreign investment in China has
climbed to 135.4 billion US dollars.


Under such circumstances, it is impossible to artificially
separate China from the rest of the world. Those who try to harm
China will harm themselves, the article said.


Moreover, China has achieved remarkable progress in all fields
with a high economic growth rate, improved comprehensive national
strength and high status in the world arena.


Attempting to contain China, which has a population of 1.2
billion, is tantamount to risking the destiny of one's own country
and a daydream, as described by former US Secretary of State Henry
Kissinger.


After the end of the Cold War peace and development have become
the main themes worldwide. All countries give priority to economic
growth and the improvement of their people's lives. Worldwide,
many problems neglected during the Cold War, such as unemployment,
poverty and drug abuse, have been brought to the top of the agenda.


However, resolving these problems needs a peaceful and stable
international environment and extensive international
co-operation. People of all countries are making endeavors and
have achieved great achievements in this respect.


Preaching containment of China runs counter to the people's
will and the historical tide. It will inevitably lead to tension,
confrontation, splits and war, the article noted.


In handling state-to-state relations, it said, it is necessary
to follow the principle of respecting the sovereignty of other
countries and not interfering in their internal affairs.


It is a flagrant violation of the United Nations Charter and
international norms to wave the stick of containment and even
advocate subverting the government of another country, the article
said.


Such acts are the result of the smashing of the dream of
unifying the world under the political and economic mode and with
the values of some people and the result of their reluctance to
see a powerful and unified China.


From ulterior motives, certain people try to put pressure on
and constantly create troubles for China and curb its development
in various ways such as by making use of issues of Taiwan, Tibet,
human rights, disarmament, nuclear testing, trade, ethnic groups
and religion. One of their latest tricks is to preach about the
"China threat" and "containment of China" in a bid to sabotage the
relations between China and its neighbors.


Facts have proved that the efforts to contain China are doomed
to failure. Though tiny, such clamor will undermine international
trust and be detrimental to world peace and stability.


Therefore, we should guard against it and curb its spread, the
article said.

results.content:
1999-04-22 
 Health Sector Publishes Statistics 


BEIJING, April 22 (Xinhua) -- Statistics released today by
China's Ministry of Health (MOH) show a drop in the number of
medical institutes, slow growth in the ranks of medical personnel
and imbalanced development for urban and rural health care
services.


China had 314,100 hospitals, clinics, disease prevention
agencies, health care centers, research institutes and medical
schools and colleges by the end of 1998, a drop of 936 on 1997.
Some 5.53 million people worked for related institutions.


The MOH report shows that some 240 hospital beds, 100 nurses
and 165 doctors were available for every 100,000 Chinese citizens.
However, the development of health care services for cities and
rural areas remains imbalanced due to investment gaps.


"Approximately 80 percent of the health care budget has been
earmarked for, with some 80 of funding going to major urban
hospitals. The development of basic health care for rural
residents, or approximately 66 percent of the total population,
remained slow due to inadequate investment," according to the
report.


Hospitals and clinics nationwide accepted 2.1 billion patient
visits last year, with some about 50 million people hospitalized
for treatment.


Patients paid an average of close to 70 yuan (8 US dollars) for
out-patient services and emergency care, with average per patient
hospitalization costs standing at 2,600 yuan. The report indicated
the health care sector curbed the rapid growth of medical
expenditures during the year.

NEWS STORY 
 2000-04-11 19:21 
 West Bank Settlers Plan New Homes  


   EFRAT, West Bank (AP) -- Bulldozers leveled ground on the
outskirts of a Jewish settlement Tuesday to prepare for 350 new
homes, a first step by settlers to challenge the government's curb
on building.


   Several settlers held up banners reading ''No to strangling
settlements'' as the bulldozers worked.


   ''We want to say that if the government won't allow the
contractor to build, we will find a way and a contractor who will
start building without permission,'' said Enon Achiman, the leader
of Efrat, a West Bank settlement south of Jerusalem.


   Settler leaders said there has been a sharp curb in settlement
construction under Prime Minister Ehud Barak, so they have
nullified an agreement to coordinate all settlement activity with
the government.


   ''Barak is afraid to publish the (construction) bids in the
newspaper, just in case (Palestinian leader Yasser) Arafat sees
them and starts making trouble,'' said Yehoshua Mor-Yosef,
spokesman for the Settlers' Council.


   Barak's government imposed a partial construction freeze in
December in an attempt to fulfill an election pledge to shift
national resources away from settlement construction.


   Kobi Bleich, spokesman for the Ministry of Housing, said that no
new bids were published for Efrat. He said the ministry approves
building ''according to need and circumstances.''


   The Palestinians, who wish to establish an independent state in
the West Bank and Gaza, maintain that the settlements are illegal
and should be dismantled as part of a final peace treaty, due in
September.


   Palestinian Cabinet Secretary Ahmed Abdel Rahman said the
settlement building makes peace efforts look insincere.


   According to the settlement watchdog group, Peace Now, the pace
of settlement building has actually increased since Barak came to
power last July. The organization says some 7,120 homes are under
construction, much more than is necessary to accommodate population
growth.

results.content:
1996-05-29 
 Chinese Capital Urged to Curb Pollution 


BEIJING, May 29 (Xinhua) -- Senior officials and environmental
protection experts have urged the Chinese capital to curb the air,
water, noise and waste pollution that has been getting serious in
recent years.


An inspection group consisting of senior officials and experts
in charge of environmental protection warned that the pollution in
this city of 12 million people is "very serious" after an
eight-day investigation.


High-energy consuming industrial enterprises, motor vehicles
and burning coal have caused severe air pollution in urban
districts, according to a report released by the group Monday.


The Capital Iron and Steel Corporation (Shougang), for example,
covers only five-thousandths of the city's territory but releases
55 percent of the city's waste gases, the report said.


Coal still accounts for more than 75 percent of fuel burned in
Beijing, compared with merely five percent of clean gas fuels.


The problem of exhaust discharge has not been effectively
solved since the number of motor vehicles has topped one million
in urban areas.


Water pollution around the city has not been controlled, and
there is a serious water supply shortage for both industrial and
household use, the report said.


Noise and domestic waste pollution have become more serious
along with the city's rapid economic and population growth in
recent years, the report noted.


During the inspection the group received about 1,600 phone
calls and 500 letters from some 6,000 citizens, who complained
about dirty air, polluted river water and vexing noises, the
"Beijing Daily" reported Tuesday.


The experts suggest the city cut the number of industrial
enterprises causing serious pollution, set up a city-wide
central-heating system, control the increase of motor vehicles and
treat much more waste water.


"Beijing will take measures to control exhaust discharge, and
industrial and noise pollution," Beijing's Mayor Li Qiyan told the
inspection group Monday.


The city's environmental protection plan also includes
protecting drinking water resources, improving waste water
treatment and strengthening management of solid wastes, according
to Li.

results.content:
1996-06-18 
 National Meeting to Be Held on Improving Environment 


BEIJING, June 18 (Xinhua) -- China will probe ways to beef up
its environmental protection law enforcement at a national
conference to be held later this year.


Xie Zhenhua, director of the State Bureau of Environmental
Protection, said the meeting, the fourth since 1949 when the
People's Republic of China was founded, will discuss ways to
implement environmental protection laws and regulations.


The meeting is part of the country's efforts to limit, by the
year 2000, its annual discharge of 12 major pollutants below that
of 1995, the director said.


In the past 18 years, China's gross national product (GNP) has
grown by ten percent each year, but has avoided a deterioration in
the environment, he said.


Xie stressed that the fulfillment of China's five-year and
15-year environmental protection goals will be an arduous task.


He explained that the country's environmental pollution and
degrading eco-system has produced a serious situation, because of
China's huge population (1.2 billion), rapid economic growth,
low-level production technology and poor management and waste of
resources.


China has taken a number of measures to curb environmental
pollution, such as improving the efficiency of resources, closing
polluting plants and introducing clean production technology.

results.content:
1998-03-16 
 Highlights of Major Beijing-based Newspapers 


BEIJING, March 16 (Xinhua) -- Highlights of today's
Beijing-based newspapers:


"People's Daily"


-- President Jiang Zemin today vowed to curb environmental
deterioration in the coming 15 years and bring an obviously better
ecological appearance to the country in 15 years.


The ongoing reshuffle inside governmental bodies at all levels
must not weaken or even affect the efforts of family planning and
environmental protection, Jiang said at a high-profile meeting
concerning the country's work on family planning and environmental
protection.


"Family planning and environmental protection are of vital
importance to sustainable economic growth while having a bearing
on the existence and development of our next generations," Jiang
said.


Premier Li Peng also said at the meeting that China must attach
great importance to family planning and environmental protection
upon which are based economic development, social progress and
people's happy lives.


-- Ten Beijing-based newspapers and news agencies joinly listed
"China's top 10 events of consumers' rights and interests been
infringed." They include Shanxi poisonous wine incident,
residents' building collapse in Zhejiang and sale of fake-brand
fur coats.


 "Xinhua Daily Telegraph"


-- The Standing Committee of the Ninth National Committee of
the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC),
China's top advisory body, opened its first meeting in Beijing
yesterday.


The two-day meeting is expected to mainly decide on the
establishment of special committees under the Ninth CPPCC National
Committee, and on candidates for the posts of chairmen and
vice-chairmen of these committees, and appoint deputy
secretaries-general of the Ninth CPPCC National Committee.


-- China has curbed its fast population growth in 1997 when the
birth rate indicated 0.041 percentage points decrease over that of
1996.


 "China Daily"


-- China's non-state-owned economy is embracing unprecedentedly
strong government support and is expected to play a vital role in
the country's economic restructuring.


The non-state sector, which has been growing faster than the
state sector, is expected to absorb the bulk of laid-off employees
from state firms, said Jing Shuping, Chairman of the all-China
Federation of Industry and Commerce, which acts as the chamber of
commerce for private businesses.


-- Landlocked central and western regions of China are hoping
that overseas investment will help them accelerate their economic
take-offs.


Provinces and autonomous regions in these areas hope that the
magic that has constantly worked in the nation's coastal areas
during the last two decades will boost their development in the
coming years.


-- The United States government has decided to give up its bid
to sponsor a United Nations Resolution critical of China's human
rights record in spite of mounting pressure from congress.


White House spokesman Eric Rubin told reporters on Saturday
that the US decision came after China agreed to sign the Covenant
on Civil and Political Rights, a move haled here as a significant
step forward.

results.content:
1997-02-04 
 New Ways Urged to Provide Quality Service in Family Planning 


BEIJING, February 4 (Xinhua) -- State Councillor Pen Peiyun has
urged that new ways be found to upgrade the quality of family
planning services in a move to further control China's rapid
population growth, today's People's Daily reported.


Pen also called for efforts to step up the reform of the
medical insurance system for urban workers during her inspection
in central China's Hunan Province from January 25 to February 1,
according to the newspaper.


It cited Pen as saying that the birth rate in Hunan has dropped
fastest among all Chinese provinces, but efforts should be
redoubled to hit a higher goal in the family planning work.


In recent years, the province has carried out successful public
education campaigns to discuss family planning, including the
medical services available for pregnant women.


The State Councillor stressed that officials and medical
workers involved in the work should be carefully trained to meet
the needs of China's future efforts in the area.


Pen also praised the work the province has done in reform of
the medical insurance system, saying experience shows that the new
system of combining social coverage with individual funding can
ensure basic medical support for workers, curb the rapid rise of
medical costs, and help the reform and development of medical
institutions.

results.content:
1996-10-31 
 Chinese Call for Greater Efforts to Eradicate Poverty 


UNITED NATIONS, October 30 (Xinhua) -- The Chinese delegation
to the United Nations today called for greater efforts to
eradicate poverty and stressed a comprehensive approach.


The fundamental way of eradicating poverty lies in helping
developing countries gradually foster their internal capability
for shaking off poverty, getting rich, and enhancing
self-accumulation mainly through their own efforts, Cui Ying, said
on behalf of the Chinese mission at a meeting today of the U.N.
Committee of Economic and Financial Affairs.


She said that in the process of poverty eradication, it is
necessary to observe the principle of sustainable development,
protect the environment, mindful of the issue of sustainable
exploitation of resources, and curb excessive population growth.


Measures in line with local realities of different countries
should be encouraged, she said.


"It is necessary to enhance multi-leveled international
cooperation of many forms," Cui said. The problem of poverty
besetting developing countries has been caused by historical
misfortunes and an unfavorable external economic environment, she
said, adding that it is, therefore, necessary to enhance
cooperation of many forms.


The Chinese representative also called for further coordination
within and outside the United Nations system.


She gave an account of China's efforts in poverty alleviation.
The number of people in poverty in the country declined to 65
million at the end of 1995 from 80 million at the end of 1993, she
said.


Despite some achievements, she said, China remains the largest
low-income country of the world, and poverty eradication remains a
heavy task.

results.content:
NEWS STORY 
 2000-05-11 18:19 
 India's Billionth Person Is Born  
By NEELESH MISRA


   NEW DELHI, India (AP) -- A bouncing baby girl named Astha
officially pushed India's population over the 1 billion mark
Thursday. Her birth was greeted with both fanfare and concern over
the nation's escalating growth rate.


   Astha -- ''faith'' in Hindi -- was born to Anjana and Ashok Arora
at 5:05 a.m. Thursday, making India only the second nation after
China to exceed a billion people.


   With an estimated 42,000 births per day in India, it was
impossible to know exactly where the billionth baby would be born,
but the government staged the milestone as part of a public
campaign to encourage Indians to have smaller families.


   Astha, wailing, was wheeled out with her sari-clad mother just
nine hours after she was born to face a crowd of government
ministers and a horde of journalists at Safdarjang Hospital in the
Indian capital. She weighed six pounds 13 ounces, doctors said.


   ''I feel fine,'' said the mother, Anjana, weak and overwhelmed
by the chaotic reception. ''I'm happy,'' said Ashok Arora, who
works in an automotive spare parts shop for a salary of $50 per
month.


   ''Don't crush the baby,'' Sumitra Mahajan, the minister for
women and child welfare, screamed into her microphone as nearly 200
journalists swarmed over the mother's bed. Hospital guards climbed
onto a nearby bed and beat back the journalists with wooden
truncheons.


   Every measure of progress India has made since independence in
1947 has been swamped by the swelling population: Food production
has tripled, yet many people go hungry; literacy has increased, but
so has the overall number of illiterate people.


   The government picked May 11 as the date -- calling it ''a moment
of celebration, a moment to ponder.'' Health Ministry officials,
with the concurrence of the U.N. Population Fund, decreed that a
baby girl born this morning in the 1,500-bed Safdarjang Hospital
would symbolically mark the milestone. Twenty-four babies were born
in Safdarjang between midnight and noon.


   The choice of a baby girl reflects another part of the
government's attempts to change Indians' family attitudes:
promoting fair treatment for infant girls to overcome traditional
biases in favor of boys.


   The last national census in 1991 said there were 927 women for
every 1,000 men in India. Health experts said that reflected a
trend in rural and poor areas that gives boys preferential
treatment in food and health care. Infanticide of baby girls
remains a problem.


   The billionth birth was hardly cause for celebration. Since its
independence, India has had little success curbing its exploding
population. When it became a nation, India had 300 million people.


   ''We welcome Astha, but we should also be thinking whether she
would get an opportunity for education and health like millions of
other children,'' said Mahajan, the government minister. ''Will we
be able to get her the resources and the opportunities necessary
for her future? This is what we have to think about.''


   Beginning this morning, a recording by the state-owned telephone
company told anyone who picked up the phone to dial in New Delhi,
''Our population has now reached 1 billion. Let's have small
families for a stronger India.''


   Projections say that if India does not curtail population growth
it will surpass China as the world's most populous nation in 50
years with 1.5 billion people.


   Efforts to encourage family planning among the poor suffered a
setback in the 1970s when the government sponsored a mass
sterilization campaign, in which poor people were duped or paid to
undergo vasectomies and tubectomies.


   The emphasis has changed in the last decade toward educating
women, raising their status and providing better health care.
Nongovernment organizations tour rural areas distributing condoms
and discussing birth control, but sex education is not taught in
the schools.
