results.content:
&HT;   



   ATLANTA _ For two decades, Cobb and Gwinnett counties have
produced record growth for metro Atlanta's north side, as sewers
and highways stretched into empty land, causing houses and
businesses to multiply like weeds. Now forecasts show the boom will
continue, putting the two counties among the hottest in the nation
well into the next century.


   Gwinnett will add 526,550 people by the year 2025, according to
Washington, D.C.-based NPA Data Services. That ranks it 19th among
all U.S. counties in projected population increase. That would put
Gwinnett at 1.02 million residents.


   NPA, a private company which compiles economic statistics and
forecasts for academics and businesses, predicts Cobb will add just
more than half a million people in the next two and a half decades.
That gives it a spot at No. 21 and a potential population of more
than 1.5 million. Most other counties topping the growth chart were
in Arizona, California and Texas.


   Job growth on the Northside also could be hot. NPA ranks
Gwinnett 19th, with the creation of 467,240 jobs by 2025, and Cobb
is projected to add 453,200 jobs. That ranks it 23rd.


   ``It's shocking to see when you put it down on paper, but based
on what's happened here in the past 25 years, it certainly doesn't
seem unrealistic,'' said Richard Tucker, Gwinnett Chamber of
Commerce president.


   ``The whole picture has changed,'' says Don Beaver, in charge of
economic development for Cobb's chamber. ``Cobb County 15 years ago
was a bedroom community, and now it's a destination point.''


   But to motorists who jam I-75 every rush hour and commuters
crawling along I-85, the first question must be: where in the world
will it all go? How can counties in the middle of a debate about
the region's sprawling development and air quality, a debate that
has reached the Legislature this year, be able to accommodate all
this new growth?


   Maybe they won't have to. Many business people and
environmentalists in both counties, who often are on opposite sides
of the growth debate, say the predictions probably won't happen.
Too many hurdles are in the way, including a ban on federal money
for road building and increasing resistance to sprawl from both
residents and officials.


   Others, though, are more optimistic, pointing to the immense
growth that has occurred in the two counties during the past few
decades. Once-rural places and crossroads now have malls and strip
shopping centers, tangles of subdivisions and busy streets. The
entire Northside has been booming, including most areas of north
Fulton.


   Gwinnett's population has nearly tripled since 1980. During that
decade it was named the fastest growing county in the country.
Cobb's has nearly doubled since then. A few decades ago, Gwinnett
had a job base for only 20 percent of its residents, meaning most
everybody else drove downtown or to other areas to work. Today,
about 60 percent of the county's work force also lives there.


   So, rural became suburban. And now, suburban is evolving into
urban.


   ``We are turning into a city,'' said Gwinnett Chairman Wayne
Hill. ``We'll always be a part of the Atlanta region, but Gwinnett
County is going to become a major player in the state. I don't see
any reason it won't, and that means it will keep growing. ... As
long as we maintain good schools and good environment, people will
want to come here.''


   But of course, therein lies the problem as well as the promise.
If Cobb and Gwinnett cannot retain the qualities that attract
newcomers, it might cause all the growth forecasts to fizzle.


   ``At some point, they hit limits,'' says Donald Ratajczak, chief
economic forecaster at Georgia State University. He believes none
of the suburban counties are planning well enough to accommodate
all the predicted growth.


   ``DeKalb ran out of residential space, and it will happen
probably to Cobb before Gwinnett,'' he said. ``I'm not saying
things are dire for them, I'm just saying that the past 20 years
can't be replicated in the next 20 years.''


   Scott Dorfman has see

results.content:
THE CENTENARIAN POPULATION EXPLOSION  
 &HT;   


 &UR; (Distributed by the New York Times Special Features) &LR;  &QC;

   (UNDATED) _ On Aug. 4, the Queen Mother celebrated her 100th
birthday. The occasion has already prompted a national service at
St. Paul's Cathedral and a huge pageant in the center of London.


   But her birthday forms part of a much bigger national and
international trend _ the remarkable rise in the number of
centenarians.


   In 1900, when Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon was born, the daughter of a
Scottish aristocrat, there were only about a hundred centenarians
in Britain. By the time she was 50, there were around 300.


   Now she joins a still select but much larger group of over
8,000, the great majority of whom are women.


   The number of centenarians has been growing at 7 percent a year.
This is a population explosion _ and one that is set to continue.
By the late 2030s, there are expected to be over 50,000 people in
the United Kingdom who have notched up the ultimate century.


   Britain is not alone in experiencing a population surge among
the very old. Worldwide, the number of centenarians is projected by
the United Nations to rise from about 150,000 today to over 2
million by 2050. What was once an extraordinary event will have
become commonplace.


   Why are so many more people living to such advanced ages?
Compare the present day with 1950, and it is clear that in Britain
one reason is simply that the number of births was higher at the
end of the 19th century than it was in 1850.


   Looking ahead, the growth in the number of centenarians will be
curbed in the second half of the next decade because of the sharp
fall in birth rates during the First World War. More important than
past changes in fertility is the sharp improvement in life
expectancy between birth and the age of 80.


   But the single most important factor _ accounting for over half
the growth in the number of centenarians in the past 50 years _ has
been the rise in survival rates from the age of 80 to 100, an age
group sometimes called the ``old old.''


   In the developed world since the 1950s some of the most
pronounced declines in death rates among adults have been at older
ages. For British men, the largest percentage drop in mortality
rates since the early 1960s has been in the 55-64 age group. For
Swedish women, the biggest percentage fall between the late 1950s
and late 1980s was among 70-year-olds.


   As yet, there is no sign that mortality declines at older ages
are slowing down, as health-care improves and the benefits of
better diet come to fruition.


   Just how long can the Queen Mother and others in her peer group
hope to live? At present, the record is held by Jeanne Calment, a
French woman who died in 1997 aged 122.


   There is no reason to believe that this represents a fixed upper
limit to life, but the current maximum age-range for centenarians
is around 110 to 115.


   However, Roger Thatcher, a former director of the census, thinks
that some of the baby-boom generation born in the late 1950s and
1960s may live to between 116 and 123.


   By the 2080s, he says, at least one person in Britain will reach
the age of 116 every year _ a remarkable thought for those
30-somethings who may live that long. And sobering for the
relations who may have to look after them.


   The rising number of centenarians highlights the gloomy concept
of ``longevity risk.'' This is the risk that you will live longer
than average.


   Someone who retires at 60 and lives to 110 is an actuary's
nightmare. No wonder annuity rates have tumbled as the pensions
industry struggles to catch up with the ``Queen Mother'' effect of
rising longevity. &QL;

   However, Roger Thatcher, a former director of the census, thinks
that some of the baby-boom generation born in the late 1950s and
1960s may live to between 116 and 123.


   By the 2080s, he says, at least one person in Britain will reach
the age of 116 every year _ a remarkable thought for those
30-somethings who may live that long. And sobering for the
relations who may have to look after them.


   The rising number of centenarians highlights the gloomy concept
of ``longevity risk.'' This is the risk that you will live longer
than average.


   Someone who retires at 60 and lives to 110 is an actuary's
nightmare. No wonder annuity rates have tumbled as the pensions
industry struggles to catch up with the ``Queen Mother'' effect of
rising longevity. &QL;

results.content:
2000-03-14 
 East African Community to Curb Illegal Arms Flow 


NAIROBI, March 14 (Xinhua) -- The East African Community (EAC),
which comprises Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda, has set up a security
committee to curb the proliferation of small arms in the region,
EAC secretary-general Francis Muthaura has said.


Kenya's local newspapers Tuesday quoted Muthaura as saying that
the flow of illegal arms into the region has contributed to the
rising rate of violent crimes and conflicts.


Muthaura on Monday told the ongoing Great Lakes Region and Horn
of Africa conference on proliferation of small arms held here that
the region has been permeated with small arms arising from current
and past conflicts.


He stressed that the illegal arms trade must be curbed to spur
economic growth in the region, saying illegal arms had deterred
development as resources were being diverted to finance wars at
the expense of economic investment.


Armed conflicts had retarded development in many eastern
African countries, making them some of the poorest in the world,
he added.

results.content:
2000-06-02 
 Symposium on Curbing Juvenile Delinquency to Be Held in Beijing 


BEIJING, June 2 (Xinhua) -- A symposium on implementing a law
to curb juvenile delinquency is scheduled to be held in Beijing
next Monday.


Li Peng, Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National
People's Congress (NPC), China's top legislature, will attend the
three-day symposium and deliver an important speech.


Senior officials from such ministries as public security and
education, and representatives from 14 provinces, municipalities
and autonomous regions are also expected to make speeches at the
symposium. Topics will include strengthening legal education
among primary and secondary school students and providing a more
healthier environment near schools.


The symposium is sponsored by the NPC Committee for Internal
and Judicial Affairs and the Central Committee of the Communist
Youth League of China.


China's top legislature approved the Law on Curbing Juvenile
Delinquency on June 28, 1999. The Law went into effect on
November 1st last year.


Wan Chaofen, vice-chairwoman of the NPC Committee for Internal
and Judicial Affairs, pointed out this morning at an new briefing
that curbing juvenile delinquency is a matter of great importance.


"It is crucial to the healthy growth of juveniles, to the
happiness of many families, and to the stability of society," she
said.


However, the rate of juvenile delinquency worldwide is on the
rise, and those teenagers violating laws or committing crimes tend
to be younger and even organize criminal gangs. China is no
exception.

results.content:
&HT;   



   ATLANTA _ Record highs have touched 100 degrees in recent days
in Cary, N.C. Substantial rain hasn't fallen for weeks.


   Still, computer programmer Robert Bonham doesn't worry about
running out of water. His grass might turn brown, but that's more a
nuisance than a crisis.


   ``The expectation is that I pay for water like I pay for cable.
I expect it to work,'' Bonham said. ``I won't think about it unless
we get to a point where there's so much growth the city can't
deliver it.''


   It's almost reached that point in Cary and other fast-growing
areas of the Deep South _ not just because of an early season
drought but also because of a decade of intense growth and
development. Booming counties and towns haven't built treatment
plants or laid pipes fast enough to keep up with surging Southern
populations.


   From 1990 to 1998, Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and Virginia
ranked in the Top 10 for people moving within their boundaries.
During that same period, the Top 10 fastest-growing counties in the
country included five from the Deep South _ four in Georgia and one
in Virginia.


   ``From a planning perspective, water is an absolute necessity,''
said Michael Vasu, a professor of public administration and
political science at North Carolina State University. ``There are
some parts of the infrastructure that you can let deteriorate to
some extent, like roads. But when there's a lack of water, you need
an immediate solution.''


   Despite a smattering of weekend rain, communities throughout the
South are restricting outdoor water use. Drought conditions exist
from south Alabama to northern Virginia.


   Even before the mercury hit the century mark in Cary, the town
council stopped accepting building applications so the community on
the edge of Research Triangle Park could figure out where to get
more water. Since 1988, Cary's population has more than doubled to
nearly 90,000 people.


   Politics designed to curb growth delayed construction of a new
water treatment plant, which may not be operating till 2003 or
later. The city currently buys 40 percent of its water supply from
Raleigh and Durham.


   A recent heat wave that pushed temperatures at the
Raleigh-Durham airport to 100 degrees for the first time in four
years has prevented municipal neighbors from sharing with Cary.


   ``There's no question that the ability to share our water
resources is a factor in future development, whether it's
residential or business,'' Vasu said. ``South Carolina is starting
to feel some of that but certainly North Carolina and Georgia are
at the forefront of all that.''


   In Columbia, S.C., where growth has been modest but steady,
Richland County Land Development Administrator Ken Knudsen has
absorbed water woes like everyone else.


   ``My water pressure is low, but whose isn't?'' he said.


   Since January, less than 10 inches of rain has fallen in
Columbia _ 6 inches less than the average for the year.


   Selling water is an industry for Columbia. It buys water from an
area electric utility then resells it to other governments. In
1998, Columbia earned more than $50 million in revenue from water
sales.


   But the deal is about to get more expensive. The utility claims
water diverted from its hydroelectric plants are undervalued and it
may increase its charges to Columbia and others by as much as 10
times current cost.


   In Georgia, severe or extreme drought conditions grip most of
the state. Several metro Atlanta areas already have imposed outdoor
watering restrictions _ including suburban boom counties like Henry
and Cherokee. Fescue lawns will go unwatered. Chevy pickups will go
unwashed. The reason: Demand exceeds delivery capability.


   ``That's the issue,'' said Pat Stevens, chief of environmental
planning for the Atlanta Regional Commission. ``I've been around
for 20 years and that's the issue. When you have that kind of
growth, the infrastructure doesn't keep up. There are restrictions
in Henry County but not in the city of Atlanta.''


   The hot, dry summer has put its traditional

results.content:
1997-04-13 
 Inflation to Fall And Economy to Grow in China 


BEIJING, April 13 (Xinhua) -- China will have a single-digit
inflation and double-digit growth in economy in the upcoming four
years, China Daily "Business Weekly" reported.


Yang Fan, a professor with the economic research institute of
the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, is quoted as saying that
low inflation gave the government a good opportunity to reform
state-owned enterprises, housing, foreign trade and financial
systems -- a must for sustained economic growth.


While low inflation would create a favorable environment for
reform, the success of the reform would be the only force strong
enough to control inflation.


Low inflation target seems reachable, as the central government
has pledged to tighten control over credit and the scale of capital
investment.


On the other hand, the supply of most of consumer goods
surpasses demand, while shortages of energy, raw materials,
transportation and telecommunications facilities have eased.
Market-oriented economic and legal measures are become effective
in curbing prices hikes.


Inflation pressure continues to be alleviated this year as the
rate fell to three percent in the first two months of the year,
down from 6.1 percent last year.


Inflation rate of last year was low compared with 14.8 percent
in 1995 and 21.7 percent in 1994.


Yang disagreed with other economists who said inflation was
beneficial to economic growth.


Revitalizing the money-losing state-owned firms is high on the
government work agenda, as is re-arranging jobs for laid-off
workers and curbing pollution.


"None of these problems can be dealt with by inflation," said
the professor, adding only restructuring of the economy can solve
them completely.


Yang believed that a ten percent growth in gross domestic
product (GDP) is appropriate, and there is no need to pursue
higher growth and the crucial task is to reform the economic
structure from investment-driven growth marked by duplicated
construction projects.


The professor held that relocation of the 30 million laid-off
workers was important, bust less important compared to the task to
ensure 1.2 billion people are not affected by serious inflation.


Unemployment would decrease through reforms that rely on stable
economic growth with low price hikes. And it is important to
tighten control over bank credit, and ensure good harvests to help
control inflation, said the professor.


Moreover, Yang praised the successful "soft landing" after high
inflation in 1993-95, and the increasing foreign exchange reserve,
from 19.4 billion U.S. dollars in 1992 to 105 billion U.S. dollars
by the end of 1996.

results.content:
2000-06-16 
 Endangered Crescent Spring Refilled 


DUNHUANG, June 16 (Xinhua) -- The water level of the Crescent
Spring, at the foot of Mingsha Hill near Dunhuang in northwest
China's Gansu Province, rose 12 centimeters in the two-week period
ending June 12, marking the welcome end of 100 years of continuous
descent.


Named for its half-moon shape, Crescent Spring, 25 km from the
Mogao Grottoes, is surrounded by sand dunes but never fills up
with sand, even when a strong wind blows. The spring water is
always clear and tranquil.


But the water level of the famed natural spring has gradually
dropped in the past 100 years due to population growth and the
loss of underground water.


According to monitoring data, the spring's water level had gone
down nine meters by 1998. The speed of descent accelerated from a
dozen centimeters a year in recent years to the present 40 cm. Now,
the area of the spring has shrunk by half, down to 5,000 square
meters.


Scholars in many countries worry about the phenomena and fear
that this unusual bit of scenery will disappear from the desert,
and threaten the safety of the world-renowned Mogao Grottoes, said
Wang Xudong, a cultural relics expert with the Dunhuang Research
Institute.


The Chinese government started rescue measures for the spring
as early as 1976, Wang said. In April of this year, the Lanzhou
Hydrological Center started a project to replenish underground
water feeding the spring.


As a result, an estimated 1,000 tons of water have seeped into
the spring each day, curbing the rapid drop of the water level.
Hydrogeologists are searching for ways to balance the rise in the
lake water and the seepage of underground water and how to control
the loss of underground water.


"If the problem is solved once and for all, it will give us a
frame of reference for desert improvement and will aid the
protection of the Mogao Grottoes," Wang said.

results.content:
UCLA ANALYSTS EXPECT STATE BOOM TO CONTINUE



   LOS ANGELES _ California's robust economy is expected to
continue to expand in the coming years, albeit at a more moderate
rate, a University of California, Los Angeles, survey predicts.


   The survey, released Wednesday by the UCLA Anderson School of
Business, also predicts nonfarm employment will rise by 3.8 percent
this year, up from 3.1 percent in 1999. A slower growth rate of 2.6
percent is expected in 2001, followed by a rate of 2.5 percent in
2002.


   ``This year will be the best year in the last decade,'' said Tom
Lieser, executive director of the Anderson Business Forecast. ``We
will also probably turn the corner and see a moderation of these
growth numbers later this year.''


   There was a large interest rate hike last month, but it doesn't
appear that it has done damage to the California economy, he said.


   At its May 16 meeting, the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee
raised the federal funds rate 50 basis points to 6.5 percent. Over
the last year the Fed has raised short-term interest rates by 1.75
percentage points in an effort to curb inflation at a time of rapid
economic growth.


   ``What the figures (in this report) show is that we are going to
have a good year in 2000, much better than anyone expected,'' said
Jack Kyser, chief economist with the Los Angeles County Economic
Development Corp.


   ``It looks like a good solid economy but there are risks,'' he
said.


   Kyser said one of the risks is another interest rate hike when
the Federal Reserve meets next week in Washington.


   Interest rate hike or not, the latest data on regional
employment trends show that Central California is leading the state
in both nonfarm employment growth and unemployment.


   Employment growth in the 10-county area was up 3.4 percent
through May from a year ago, compared with 3.0 percent for the
seven counties in Southern California and 2.8 percent for the
counties of the San Francisco Bay and Sacramento areas combined.


   With the exception of the Stockton-Lodi area, Central California
continues to experience double-digit rates of unemployment.
Unemployment rates are highest in Fresno County, 13.5 percent, and
Merced County, 13.4 percent, the report said.


   The high unemployment figures reflect the fact that Central
California's economy is based on agriculture, said Kyser.


   In Southern California, inland Riverside and San Bernardino
counties continued to lead in employment growth - an increase of
5.5 percent through May.


   ``They are making a transition from an agricultural to an
urbanized ... economy,'' he said. ``A lot of manufacturing firms
are moving from Los Angeles and Orange counties. Also, Palm Springs
has become a year-round economy, not one just based on tourism.''


   Employment grew by 2.2 percent for the year to date in Los
Angeles County, compared with 1.6 percent in 1999. In San Jose in
Santa Clara County, it was up by 2.1 percent vs. 1.3 percent in
1999.


   The survey also forecasts permits in 2000 for 154,000 housing
units, declining slightly in 2001 to 151,000 before rebounding the
next year to 159,000.


   With limited new housing coming to the market, prices continue
to increase. For Los Angeles County, the average price of a home
was predicted to increase by 5.9 percent this year, according to
the survey.


   While home prices continued to outpace construction, the survey
also found that consumer spending was expected to remain at record
levels before experiencing a slight slowdown in 2001 and 2002.


   Consumer spending, as measured by taxable sales, will continue
to reflect gains in personal income and employment in the coming
year. The exceptional impact from large amounts of wealth created
in recent years should continue, the report said.


   According to Lieser, California will enjoy a 7.8 percent
increase in taxable sales this year, which will be followed by
slower gains of 6.3 percent in 2001 and 6.1 percent in 2002.

order for us to see such

results.content:
China plans new measures to protect farmland, curb floods


	   BEIJING (AP) _ To prevent further losses of precious farmland
needed to feed the world's biggest population, China's new minister
of land and resources promised Friday strict controls in a new
land-use law.
	   Effective Jan. 1, the revised land-use law will make it harder
to take land out of farming, Zhou Yongkang said at a briefing.
	   The government plans ``very rigorous measures to improve land
resources management and environmental protection,'' Zhou said.
	   Previous land use and environmental laws have failed to prevent
a severe decline in farmland. From 1986 through 1995, nearly 6.7
million hectares (16.5 million acres) of farmland were lost to
disasters and development, according to a government report
released Friday.
	   Lax enforcement of environmental laws and rampant deforestation
_ leading to soil erosion and silting of riverbeds _ were a major
factor behind floods that killed more than 3,000 people this
summer, the government has acknowledged.
	   In response to the flooding, effective Sept. 1 the government
banned logging along the upper reaches of the Yangtze River.
	   Zhou refused to answer reporters' questions about how the
central government would pay for the shift from logging to
reforestation, estimated by Sichuan provincial officials to cost
more than 1 billion yuan (dlrs 120 million) annually, and prevent
illegal logging.
	   The government also plans to take some land on steep hillsides
or along rivers and lakes out of farming to help prevent floods.
	   Zhou admitted the process would be gradual, as farmers and
loggers are moved from mountainsides to wasteland on the plains in
Sichuan to farm.
	   ``The process affects people's livelihoods, so we'll be adopting
a very cautious strategy,'' he said.
	   The worst flooding since 1954 on the Yangtze River laid bare the
cost of China's choice of putting fast growth ahead of
environmental protection.
	   Sedimentation has reduced the volume of China's huge freshwater
lakes along the Yangtze _ which served as natural diversion tanks
for floodwaters _ by 40 percent, according to figures released
Friday.
	   The land agency's report Friday was one of the first to use new
estimates that show China has about 40 percent more farmland than
previously acknowledged. But even the higher number still leaves
China with a small amount of farmland compared to its population:
just under 10 percent of the world's farmland for 22 percent of the
world's population.
	   According to the new data, China has 128 million hectares (316
million acres) of farmland, or about 14 percent of its total land,
compared with the 93 million hectares (230 million acres) reported
until recently but long known to be an underestimate.
	   The new figure was calculated using satellite photography. The
old one was compiled from reports by local officials who tended
underreport land area to lower their tax bases or exaggerate
productivity.

results.content:
1998-06-22 
 Chinese Trade Minister Calls for Efforts to Curb Yen's Devaluation 


BEIJING, June 22 (Xinhua) -- Both Japan and the United States
are urged to take effective measures to curb the further
devaluation of Japanese Yen, Chinese top trade official said in a
press conference here today.


"The slide of Japanese Yen has produced an adverse effect not
only on China's economic growth but on the economic stability
across the Asian continent," Shi Guangsheng, minister of Foreign
Trade and Economic Cooperation, noted in response to a question on
Yen's devaluation in the international monetary market.


"Japan, as an economic power in Asia, should play a
responsible role in the regional economy," Shi said.

results.content:
2000-09-24 
 Swiss Vote Down Proposal to Restrict Number of Foreigners 


GENEVA, September 24 (Xinhua) -- The Swiss people rejected a
proposal to reduce the number of foreign residents to 18 percent
of the population in a nationwide referendum Sunday.


The move to curb the number of foreigners was voted down by 63
percent, with 37 percent in favor. This is the seventh time that
the Swiss have rejected similar moves to curb the level of
foreigners since 1970.


The "no" vote has been welcomed by the government and big
businesses. Speaking for the government, Swiss Justice Minister
Ruth Metzler welcomed the result. She said that it was a signal to
the international community that Switzerland was willing to adhere
to its commitments.


Leading party politicians and business figures welcomed the
outcome, saying that reason had prevailed over emotion. The head
of the main employers' organization, Peter Hasler, echoed the
sentiment. He said the Swiss people had not wanted to jeopardize
the country's humanitarian tradition or Switzerland's image abroad.


It is estimated that foreign residents in Switzerland account
for more than 19 percent of the country's population of about 7.1
million.

results.content:
TAINTED FOOD, WATER DRAWS COUNTY'S EYE 



   (PHOENIX) - Maricopa County has nearly three times the number of
illnesses caused by tainted food and water than a community of this
size should have, the county's top health official says.


   And two-thirds of those cases were never investigated because of
a lack of staff and money, says Dr. Jonathan Weisbuch, director of
the county's Department of Public Health.


   ``The causes could be any one of a million things,'' he said,
ranging from improperly cooked meals in homes or businesses to
people not washing their hands before they prepare food or eat.


   ``The fact is, we simply don't know the causes. And if we don't
know, then we can't do anything about it.''


   That's why Weisbuch says the department needs more money, about
$130,000 from the county's general fund, this year to help pay for
an epidemiologist, a specially trained nurse and an investigator to
find out what's making so many people sick.


   The county Board of Supervisors could vote within 30 days on the
health department's requested budget increase, Chairman Andrew
Kunasek said.


   Maricopa County currently investigates about a third of the
4,000 annual reports of food-borne and water-borne illnesses. If
the additional funds are approved, Weisbuch said, the county would
be able to investigate most of the remaining cases.


   Among the cases that were investigated last year include a
September outbreak in which 500 county jail inmates suffered
nausea, stomach cramps and vomiting. Lab tests indicate the cause
may have been a tainted dinner.


   Another incident last year involved 21 people who became ill
after drinking unpasteurized orange juice blended by a Tempe-based
company. That company, Sun Orchard, stopped producing unpasteurized
orange juice.


   The caseload of 4,000 reported food- and water-borne illnesses
is nearly three times higher than it should be for a community of
this size, based on a recent study from the national Centers for
Disease Control and Prevention, Weisbuch said. The expected rate of
these illnesses is about 50 cases per 100,000 people, he said.


   By that count, the Phoenix area should have had 1,500 cases,
instead of 4,000.


   Weisbuch said the high number may be partly due to population
growth:


   ``We are adding 100,000 people every year to this community, and
1,000 new food businesses,'' he said.


   People new to the Phoenix area may need time to figure out how
to properly store or prepare foods that are more common to this
area, Weisbuch said. Even something as simple as leaving groceries
in a car for too long in the summer can foster bacteria growth to
unhealthful levels.


   Improper temperature is a leading cause of food contamination,
said David Ludwig, who is in charge of the food service inspections
division of Maricopa County Environmental Services.


   Some foods need to be heated to at least 190 degrees to kill off
bacteria. Others foods need to be stored at low temperatures to
curb growth of bacteria.


   There's a complicated set of heating and cooling procedures
needed for cooking, reheating, storing and serving different kinds
of foods, Ludwig said. Otherwise, bacteria could grow to the point
that they could cause illness. &QL; 
 &QL;

Ryan.Konig(at)Arizona &QL; 
Republic.com or (602) 444-7425. &QL;

results.content:
&HT;   



   ATLANTA _ Before Y2K, the world will have to deal with Y6B _ the
year of 6 billion.


   The United Nations says the world's 6 billionth baby will be
born Oct. 12. The U.S. Census Bureau estimated it already happened
Sunday.


   As Earth's human population crosses the 6 billion threshold,
international development agencies with ties to Atlanta are working
hard to stem the growth _ not because the planet cannot sustain so
many people but because high population growth threatens efforts to
improve the lives of the world's poor.


   The U.N. Foundation, set up to distribute Atlanta businessman
Ted Turner's $1 billion gift to U.N.-related causes, has made
population control one of its main focuses.


   The Carter Center is concentrating on food supply and ways to
improve health delivery systems in 25 countries.


   And the relief agency CARE, an organization that had no family
planning program as recently as 1991, now helps offer birth control
to 4 million people in 36 countries, said Maurice Middleberg, the
organization's director of health and population programs.


   ``Our goal, God willing, is that we will serve over the next
five years something on the order of 14 million,'' Middleberg said.


   Fourteen million. Six billion. What do the numbers mean? To put
it in perspective, consider that one-tenth of all the people who
have ever lived on planet Earth are alive today.


   ``In 1800, the world's population reached 1 billion. By 1930, it
was 2 billion. Now, we're heading toward 6 billion,'' said Peter
Bahouth, executive director of the Turner Foundation. ``The world's
population is increasing by 78 million people a year _ that's the
population of Greece, Sweden and France combined.''


   Since the time his boss Turner was born roughly 60 years ago,
the world has added 2 billion people, Bahouth said. ``That's
amazing. It's just an incredible statistic.''


   Even though fertility rates are decreasing, the United Nations
projects a population of 9 billion by 2050. Bahouth said the growth
rate will not stabilize for years because of what is known as
``demographic momentum.''


   ``There are already so many young people,'' he said.


   Many of the 1 billion people ages 15 to 24 and the 2 billion
under age 15 are destined to become parents. That's why the Turner
Foundation is focusing special attention on adolescents.


   ``There is the largest ever group of adolescents that the world
has ever seen,'' said Ellen Marshall, program officer for
population and women for the U.N. Foundation. ``Looking at what
(adolescents') opportunities are and the decisions they make is
going to have an enormous impact on their countries and the
world.''


   In Georgia, for example, the Turner Foundation funds the Georgia
Campaign for Adolescent Pregnancy and Prevention, which, Bahouth
said, concentrates on providing good health care and opportunities
for youths without early pregnancy.


   Such educational programs coupled with better access to
contraception are the only way to start curbing population growth,
experts say. But a variety of economic and cultural reasons hamper
access to birth control for women in developing nations.


   Agencies like CARE, which has its U.S. headquarters in Atlanta,
have taken on the task of easing accessibility. In Ghana, for
example, CARE trains hairdressers on how to use condoms so that
they can show their customers.


   ``(People) get their hair done, and while they're waiting, they
also pick up their contraceptives,'' said spokeswoman Cynthia
Glocker.


   Even where there is availability of birth control, bad
information often abounds.


   ``You talk to women, and they'll say things like: `Is the IUD
going to float in my body? I've heard stories that it enters my
lungs. Or the pill gives you cancer,''' said CARE's Middleberg.


   A problem, say family planning workers, is that it takes a long
time to change perceptions and beliefs, and ultimately, ways of
life.


   ``It takes years to see results,'' said Gordon Streeb, associate
executive director of the Carter Center.

results.content:
Makers of chemical sterilization pellets halt production 


	   SISSELN, Switzerland (AP) _ Sipharm Sisseln AG is halting
production of chemical pellets used in the irreversible
sterilizations of more than 100,000 women in poor countries.
	   Executives of Sipharm Sisseln AG, based in Sisseln, Switzerland,
said Friday they took the step because of the controversy that
erupted after the Wall Street Journal reported last week on how the
drug was being used.
	   The drug, called quinacrine, originally was intended to fight
malaria. Inserted into the uterus, it prevents pregnancies by
scarring the fallopian tubes.
	   Quinacrine isn't approved by the U.S. Food and Drug
Administration for use in the United States because of the possible
dangers, including a suggested link to cancer.
	   Nearly all major family-planning organizations, many foreign
governments and the World Health Organization also oppose its use
for sterilization.
	   Sipharm Sisseln Vice President Fritz Schneiter said his company
had nothing to do with the actual use of the pellets. He also said
it hadn't been warned by the WHO about the way the drug was being
used.
	   Sipharm said it has produced around 2 million of the pellets for
the Center for Research on Population and Security and another
organization in the United States, the International Federation for
Family Health. It has also produced one million pellets for the
International Association for Maternal and Neonatal Health in
Switzerland.
	   The U.S. center is run by contraceptive researcher Stephen D.
Mumford, 55, of North Carolina, and his colleague, Dr. Elton
Kessel, 79, of Oregon.
	   They paid for the pellets' manufacture in Switzerland and
arrange for its free distribution in poor nations through a network
of doctors, nurses and midwives. Mumford claims women in Asia
prefer it to surgical sterilization and that it is cheap and safe.
	   Operating on a tiny budget out of Mumford's home, the two hope
to use the drug to curb population growth and limit the flow of
immigrants to the United States.
	   Their primary goal, Mumford said, is to improve the lives and
protect the health of Third World women, almost 600,000 of whom die
each year from pregnancy-related complications.

results.content:
1996-12-01 
 Scientists Find Cancer-Curbing Gene 


OTTAWA, November 30 (Xinhua) -- Scientists at Canada's
University of Calgary have discovered a gene that curbs the growth
of several cancers, the newspaper Globe and Mail said today.


The finding has immediate implications for diagnosing the
presence of a cancer and appears to have a potential for treatment
in humans, said Dr. Karl Riabawol, a medical researcher with the
university.


Known as ING-1, the gene is a tumor suppressor and is active in
healthy cells, producing a substance that controls growth. In
cancer cells, it is shut off or mutated, the paper said.


The gene was first discovered when normal breast cells were
compared with breast tumor cells. And the same result has been
seen in five other types of human cancer.


Laboratory experiments show that active ING-1 genes stopped the
growth of each of these types of cancer cells, Riabawol said.


The next step in the research will be to understand what
factors turn off the gene, he said.

results.content:
WILL HUMANS OVERWHELM THE EARTH? THE DEBATE GOES ON 



   PHILADELPHIA _ Two hundred years ago the Rev. Thomas Robert
Malthus, an English economist and mathematician, anonymously
published an essay predicting that the world's burgeoning human
population would overwhelm the earth's capacity to feed it.


   Malthus' gloomy forecast, called ``An Essay on the Principle of
Population As it Affects the Future Improvement of Society,'' was
condemned by Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels and many other theorists,
and it was still striking sparks last week at a meeting in
Philadelphia of the American Anthropological Society. Despite
continuing controversy, it was clear that Malthus' conjectures are
far from dead.


   Among the scores of special conferences organized for the 5,000
participating anthropologists, many touched directly or indirectly
on the dilemma suggested by Malthus: Although global food supplies
increase arithmetically, the population increases geometrically _ a
vastly faster rate.


   The consequence, Malthus believed, was that poverty, and the
misery it imposes, will inevitably increase unless the increase in
population is curbed.


   This contention has prompted endless debate. Malthus' critics
have argued that man's ingenuity will always keep pace with
population growth by finding improved ways to produce food. They
cite the success of the ``Green Revolution'' launched in the 1950s
and 1960s by Dr. Norman Borlaug and his associates in developing
high-yield strains of rice and wheat.


   But the scientific descendants of Malthus argue that feeding the
world's masses is only part of the problem. Just as dangerous, they
contend, is the omnivorous consumption of nonrenewable resources,
the irreversible destruction of habitats and species, the fouling
of the air and seas and consequent changes in climate, and many
other effects of a growing human horde.


   One of the symposiums held at last week's meeting was regarded
as so contentious that a similar conference was banned from the
1994 meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of
Science, on the grounds _ said its organizer, Dr. Warren Hern, a
Colorado physician and epidemiologist _ that ``you may not ask that
question.''


   The question, posed as the title of the symposium, was this:
``Is the Human Species a Cancer on the Planet?''


   Hern, the director of an abortion clinic in Boulder, Colo.,
noticed nearly a decade ago that aerial and satellite views of
urban centers taken over a period of years bore a striking
similarity to images of cancerous tissue _ particularly melanoma _
invading the healthy surrounding tissue.


   In his presentation last week, Hern argued that in many parts of
the world the increase in human numbers is rapid and uncontrolled,
that it invades and destroys habitats, and that by killing off many
species it reduces the differentiation of nature. All of these
features are characteristic of cancerous tumors, he said.


   This assessment was applauded by another member of the panel,
Dr. Lynn Margulis of the University of Massachusetts in Boston, who
is the co-author of another highly debated theory, the Gaia
Hypothesis.


   The hypothesis, the brainchild of an English theorist, Dr. James
Lovelock and Dr. Margulis, who is a microbiologist, is that the
earth deploys feedback mechanisms to maintain an environment
hospitable to life. In this it resembles a gigantic living
organism, proponents of the Gaia idea believe.


   Life on earth has survived many crises, including mass
extinctions caused by the impacts of asteroids and comets, Dr.
Margulis said, and life will continue despite the threats created
by humanity _ but with reduced diversity.


   She agreed with the notion that the human race is a kind of
self-destructive cancer.


   ``For millions of years,'' she said, ``the earth got along
without human beings, and it will do so again. The only question is
the nature of the human demise that has already begun.''


   Dr. Margulis quoted a line from the German philosopher Friedrich
Nietzsche: ``The earth is a beautiful
